edition.title: The first parte of the history of the life of Sir John Oldcastell lord Cobham
edition.note: Two 1600 quartos. One Q1 edition had a false date of 1600 so not included here.

edition.printer: Roger Daniel, John Hayous, Alice Warren

persona.persname: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham
Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: The doubtful Title (Gentlemen) prefix’d
Upon the argument we have in hand,
May breed suspense, and wrongfully disturb
The peaceful quiet of your settled thoughts.
To stop which scruple, let this brief suffice:
It is no pampered glutton we present,
Nor aged counselor to youthful sin,
But one, whose virtue shone above the rest,
A valiant martyr and a virtuous peer;
In whose true faith and loyalty expressed
Unto his sovereign, and his country’s weal,
We strive to pay that tribute of our love,
Your favors merit. Let fair truth be graced,
Since forged invention former time defaced.

scene.scenelocation: Hereford. A street.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Herbert, Lord Powis, Owen, Gough, Davy, and several other followers of the lords Herbert and Powis.
They fight. In the fight, enter the Sheriff and two of his bailiffs.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: My Lords, I charge you in his Highness’ name,
To keep the peace, you, and your followers.

speech.speaker: HERB.
speech.line: Good Master Sheriff, look unto yourself.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Do so, for we have other business.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Will you disturb the judges, and the assize?
Hear the King’s proclamation, you were best.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Hold then, let’s hear it.

speech.speaker: HERB.
speech.line: But be brief, you were best.

speech.speaker: 1. BAIL.
speech.line: O yes!

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Cousin, make shorter “O” or shall mar your “Yes".

speech.speaker: 1. BAIL.
speech.line: O yes!

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: What, has her nothing to say but “O yes"?

speech.speaker: 1. BAIL.
speech.line: O yes!

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: O nay! Pyou cosse plut down with her, down with her!
A Pawesse! A Pawesse!

speech.speaker: GOUGH.
speech.line: A Herbert! A Herbert! And down with Powis!

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Hold, in the king’s name. Hold.

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: Down i’ tha knave’s name. Down.

stagedir.dir: In this fight, the Bailiff is knocked down, and the Sheriff and the Bailiffs run away.

speech.speaker: HERB.
speech.line: Powis, I think thy Welsh and thou do smart.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Herbert, I think my sword came near thy heart.

speech.speaker: HERB.
speech.line: Thy heart’s best blood shall pay the loss of mine.

speech.speaker: GOUGH.
speech.line: A Herbert! A Herbert!

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: A Pawesse! A Pawesse!

stagedir.dir: As they are lifting their weapons, enter the Mayor of Hereford, and his Officers, Sergeant, and Townsmen with clubs.

speech.speaker: HERE.
speech.line: My lords, as you are liege men to the crown,
True noblemen, and subjects to the king,
Attend his Highness’ proclamation,
Commanded by the judges of assize,
For keeping peace at this assembly.

speech.speaker: HERB.
speech.line: Good Master Mayor of Hereford, be brief.

speech.speaker: HERE.
speech.line: Sergeant, without the ceremony of O yes,
Pronounce aloud the proclamation.

speech.speaker: SERG.
speech.line: The king’s justices, perceiving what public mischief may ensue this private quarrel, in his majesty’s name do straightly charge and command all persons, of what-degree-soever, to depart this city of Hereford, except such as are bound to give attendance at this assize, and that no man presume to wear any weapon, especially Welsh-hooks, forest bills—

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: Haw, no pill nor wells hoog? Ha?

speech.speaker: HERE.
speech.line: Peace, and hear the proclamation.

speech.speaker: SERG.
speech.line: And that the Lord Powis do presently disperse and discharge his retinue, and depart the city in the king’s peace, he and his followers, on pain of imprisonment.

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Haw? Pud her Lord Pawesse in prison? A Pawesse!
A Pawesse! Cossone live and tie with her lord.

speech.speaker: GOUGH.
speech.line: A Herbert! A Herbert!

stagedir.dir: In this fight the Lord Herbert is wounded, and falls to the ground. The Mayor of Hereford and his company go away, crying clubs. Powis runs away. Gough and other of Herbert’s faction busy themselves about Herbert. Enter the two judges in their robes, the Sheriff and his Bailiffs before them.

speech.speaker: 1. JUDGE.
speech.line: Where’s the Lord Herbert? Is he hurt or slain?

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: He’s here, my lord.

speech.speaker: 2. JUDGE.
speech.line: How fares his lordship, friends?

speech.speaker: GOUGH.
speech.line: Mortally wounded, speechless. He cannot live.

speech.speaker: 1. JUDGE.
speech.line: Convey him hence; let not his wounds take air,
And get him dressed with expedition.
Master Mayor of Hereford, Master Shrieve o’ the shire,
Commit Lord Powis to safe custody,
To answer the disturbance of the peace,
Lord Herbert’s peril, and his high contempt
Of us, and you the king’s commissioners.
See it be done with care and diligence.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Please it your lordship. My Lord Powis is gone
Past all recovery.

speech.speaker: 2. JUDGE.
speech.line: Yet let search be made,
To apprehend his followers that are left.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: There are some of them. Sirs, lay hold of them.

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: Of us? And why? What has here done, I pray you?

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Disarm them, bailiffs.

speech.speaker: HERE.
speech.line: Officers, assist.

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Hear you, lor shudge, what resson is for this?

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: Cosson pe puse for fighting for our lord?

speech.speaker: 1. JUDGE.
speech.line: Away with them.

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Harg you, my lord.

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: Gough my Lord Herbert’s man’s a shitten knave.

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Ise live and tie in good quarrel.

speech.speaker: OWEN.
speech.line: Pray you do shustice; let all be preson.

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Prison! No.
Lord shudge, I wool give you pale, good suerty.

speech.speaker: 2. JUDGE.
speech.line: What bail? What sureties?

speech.speaker: DAVY.
speech.line: Her coozin ap Ries, ap Evan, ap Morris, ap Morgan, ap
Lluellyn, ap Madoc, ap Meredith, ap Griffen, ap Davy, ap
Owen, ap Shinken Shones.

speech.speaker: 2. JUDGE.
speech.line: Two of the most sufficient are y’now.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: And ’t please your lordship, these are all but one.

speech.speaker: 1. JUDGE.
speech.line: To jail with them, and the Lord Herbert’s men;
We’ll talk with them, when the assize is done.
Riotous, audacious, and unruly grooms.
Must we be forced to come from the bench,
To quiet brawls, which every constable
In other civil places can suppress?

speech.speaker: 2. JUDGE.
speech.line: What was the quarrel that caused all this stir?

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: About religion, as I heard, my lord.
Lord Powis detracted from the power of Rome,
Affirming Wickliffe’s doctrine to be true,
And Rome’s erroneous. Hot reply was made
By the lord Herbert, they were traitors all
That would maintain it: Powis answered,
They were as true, as noble, and as wise
As he, that would defend it with their lives;
He named for instance Sir John Oldcastle,
The Lord Cobham: Herbert replied again,
“He, thou, and all are traitors that so hold.”
The lie was given, the several factions drawn,
And so enraged, that we could not appease it.

speech.speaker: 1. JUDGE.
speech.line: This case concerns the King’s prerogative,
And’s dangerous to the State and common wealth.
Gentlemen, justices, master Mayor, and master Shrieve,
It doth behoove us all, and each of us
In general and particular, to have care
For suppressing of all mutinies,
And all assemblies, except soldiers’ musters
For the king’s preparation into France.
We hear of secret conventicles made,
And there is doubt of some conspiracies,
Which may break out into rebellious arms
When the king’s gone, perchance before he go:
Note as an instance, this one perilous fray;
What factions might have grown on either part,
To the destruction of the king and realm.
Yet, in my conscience, Sir John Oldcastle,
Innocent of it, only his name was used.
We, therefore, from his Highness give this charge:
You, master Mayor, look to your citizens;
You, master Sheriff, unto your shire; and you
As justices, in every one’s precinct,
There be no meetings. When the vulgar sort
Sit on their ale-bench, with their cups and cans,
Matters of state be not their common talk,
Nor pure religion by their lips profaned.
Let us return unto the bench again,
And there examine further of this fray.

speech.speaker: SHER.
speech.line: Sirs, have you taken the Lord Powis yet?

speech.speaker: 1. BAIL.
speech.line: No, nor heard of him.

speech.speaker: 2. BAIL.
speech.line: No, he’s gone far enough.

speech.speaker: 2. JUDGE.
speech.line: They that are left behind shall answer all.

scene.scenelocation: Eltham. An antechamber in the palace.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: Enter Duke of Suffolk, Bishop of Rochester, Master Butler, and Sir John the Parson.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Now, my lord Bishop, take free liberty
To speak your mind: what is your suit to us?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: My noble Lord, no more than what you know,
And have been oftentimes invested with:
Grievous complaints have past between the lips
Of envious persons to upbraid the clergy,
Some carping at the livings which we have,
And others spurning at the ceremonies
That are of ancient custom in the church.
Amongst the which, Lord Cobham is a chief:
What inconvenience may proceed hereof,
Both to the King and to the commonwealth,
May easily be discerned, when like a frenzy
This innovation shall possess their minds.
These upstarts will have followers, to uphold
Their damned opinion, more than Harry shall
To undergo his quarrel ‘gainst the French.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: What proof is there against them to be had,
That what you say the law may justify?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: They give themselves the name of Protestants,
And meet in fields and solitary groves.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Was ever heard, my lord, the like til now?
That thieves and rebels—S’blood, heretics,
Plain heretics, I’ll stand tooth to their teeth—
Should have, to color their vile practices,
A title of such worth as Protestant?

stagedir.dir: Enter bishop’s servant with a letter.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: O, but you must not swear; it ill becomes
One of your coat to rap out bloody oaths.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Pardon him, good my lord, it is his zeal;
An honest country prelate, who laments
To see such foul disorder in the church.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: There’s one—they call him Sir John Oldcastle—
He has not his name for naught: for like a castle
Doth he encompass them within his walls;
But till that castle be subverted quite,
We ne’er shall be at quiet in the realm.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: That is not our suit, my Lord, that he be ta’en,
And brought in question for his heresy.
Beside, two letters brought me out of Wales,
Wherein my Lord Hereford writes to me,
What tumult and sedition was begun,
About the Lord Cobham at the Sises there,
(For they had much ado the calm the rage),
And that the valiant Herbert is there slain.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: A fire that must be quenched. Well, say no more,
The king anon goes to the counsel chamber,
There to debate of matters touching France:
As he doth pass by, I’ll inform his grace
Concerning your petition. Master Butler,
If I forget, do you remember me.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: I will, my lord.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Not for a recompense,
But as a token of our love to you,
By me my lords of the clergy do present
This purse, and in it full a thousand angels,
Praying your lordship to accept their gift.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: I thank them, my Lord Bishop, for their love,
But will not take they money. If you please
To give it to this gentleman, you may.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Sir, then we crave your furtherance herein.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: The best I can, my Lord of Rochester.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Nay, pray you take it. Trust me, but you shall.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Were you all thee upon New Market heath,
You should not need strain curtsy who should ha’t;
Sir John would quickly rid you of that care.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: The king is coming. Fear you not, my lord.
The very first thing I will break with him
Shall be about your matter.

stagedir.dir: Enter King Henry and Earl of Huntington in talk.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: My Lord of Suffolk,
Was it not said the clergy did refuse
To lend us money toward our wars in France?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: It was, my lord, but very wrongfully.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I know it was, for Huntington here tells me,
They have been very bountiful of late.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: And still they vow, my gracious Lord, to be so,
Hoping your majesty will think of them
As of your loving subjects, and suppress
All such malicious errors as begin
To spot their calling, and disturb the church.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: God else forbid. Why, Suffolk, is there
Any new rupture to disquiet them?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: No new, my Lord; the old is great enough,
And so increasing as, if not cut down,
Will breed a scandal to your royal state,
And set your Kingdom quickly in an uproar.
The Kentish knight, Lord Cobham, in despite
Of any law, or spiritual discipline,
Maintains this upstart new religion still,
And divers great assemblies by his means
And private quarrels are commenced abroad,
As by this letter more at large, my liege,
Is made apparent.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We do find it here:
There was in Wales a certain fray of late,
Between two noblemen, but what of this?
Follows it straight, Lord Cobham must be he
Did cause the same? I dare be sworn, good knight,
He never dreamt of any such contention.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: But in his name the quarrel did begin,
About the opinion which he held, my liege.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How if it did? Was either he in place,
To take part with them, or abet them in it?
If brabling fellows, whose inkindled blood,
Seethes in their fiery veins, will needs go fight,
Making their quarrels of some words that past
Either of you, or you, amongst their cups,
Is the fault yours, or are they guilty of it?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: With pardon of your Highness, my dread lord,
Such little sparks, neglected, may in time
Grow to a might flame: but that’s not all;
He doth, beside, maintain a strange religion,
And will not be compelled to come to mass.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: We do beseech you, therefore, gracious prince,
Without offense unto your majesty,
We may be bold to use authority.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: As how?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: To summon him unto the arches,
Where such offenses have their punishment.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: To answer personally? Is that your meaning?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: It is, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How, if he appeal?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: He cannot, my lord, in such a case as this.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Not where religion is the plea, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I took it always, that our self stood out,
As a sufficient refuge, unto whom
Not any but might lawfully appeal.
But we’ll not argue now upon that point.
For Sir John Oldcastle, whom you accuse,
Let me entreat you to dispense awhile
With your high title of preeminence.
Report did never yet condemn him so,
But he hath always been reputed loyal:
And in my knowledge I can say thus much,
That he is virtuous, wise, and honorable.
If any way his conscience be seduced,
To waver in his faith, I’ll send for him,
And school him privately; if that serve not,
Then afterward you may proceed against him.
Butler, be you the messenger for us,
And will him presently repair to court.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: How now, my lord, why stand you discontent?
In sooth, me thinks the King hath well decreed.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Yea, yea, sir John, if he would keep his word;
But I perceive he favors him so much,
As this will be to small effect, I fear.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Why, then, I’ll tell you what y’are bets to do:
If you suspect the King will be but cold
In reprehending him, send you a process too
To serve upon him: so you may be sure
To make him answer ’t, howsoe’er it fall.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: And well remembered! I will have it so.
A Sumner shall be sent about it straight.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Yea, do so. In the mean space this remains
For kind Sir John of Wrotham, honest Jack.
Methinks the purse of gold the Bishop gave
Made a good show; it had a tempting look.
Beshrew me, but my fingers’ ends to itch
To be upon those rudduks. Well, ‘tis thus:
I am not as the world does take me for;
If ever wolf were clothed in sheep’s coat,
Then I am he,—old huddle and twang, i’faith,
A priest in show, but in plain terms a thief.
Yet, let me tell you too, an honest thief,
One that will take it where it may be spared,
And spend it freely in good fellowship.
I have as many shapes as Proteus had,
That still, when any villainy is done,
There may be none suspect it was sir John.
Besides, to comfort me,—for what’s this life,
Except the crabbed bitterness thereof,
Be sweetened now and then with lechery?—
I have my Doll, my concubine, as ‘twere,
To frolic with, a lusty bouncing girl.
But whilst I loiter here, the gold may scape,
And that must not be so. It is mine own;
Therefore, I’ll meet him on his way to court,
And shrive him of it: there will be the sport.

scene.scenelocation: Kent. An outer court before Lord Cobham’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter three or four poor people: some soldiers, some old men.

speech.speaker: 1. POOR CIT.
speech.line: God help! God help! There’s law for punishing,
But there’s no law for our necessity:
There be more stocks to set poor soldiers in,
Than there be houses to relieve them at.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: Faith, housekeeping decays in every place,
Even as Saint Peter writ, still worse and worse.

speech.speaker: 3. POOR CIT.
speech.line: Master Mayor of Rochester has given commandment, that none shall go abroad out of the parish; and they have set an order down forsooth, what every poor householder must give towards our relief. Where there be some ceased, I may say to you, had almost as much need to beg as we.

speech.speaker: 1. POOR CIT.
speech.line: It is a hard world the while.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: If a poor man come to a door to ask for God’s sake, they ask him for a license, or a certificate from a justice.

speech.speaker: 2. POOR CIT.
speech.line: Faith we have none but what we bear upon our bodies, our maimed limbs. God help us.

speech.speaker: 3. POOR CIT.
speech.line: And yet, as lame as I am, I’ll with the King into France, if I can crawl but a shipboard. I had rather be slain in France, than starve in England.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: Ha, were I but as lusty as I was at the battle of Shrewbury, I would not do as I do: but we are now come to the good lord Cobham’s, to the best man to the poor that is in all Kent.

speech.speaker: 3. POOR CIT.
speech.line: God bless him! There be but few such.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Thou peevish, froward man, what wouldst thou have?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: This pride, this pride, brings all to beggary.
I served your father, and your grandfather;
Show me such two men now!
No! No! Your backs, your backs, the devil and pride,
Has cut the throat of all good housekeeping.—
They were the best Yeomens’ masters,
That ever were in England.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Yea, except thou have a crew of seely knaves
And sturdy rogues still feeding at my gate,
There is no hospitality with thee.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: They may sit at the gat well enough, but the devil of any thing you give them, except they will eat stones.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Tis long, then, of such hungry knaves as you.
Yea, sir, here’s your retinue; your guests be come.
They know their hours, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: God bless your honor! God save the good Lord Cobham
And all his house!

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Good your honor, bestow your blessed alms
Upon poor men.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Now, sir, here be your alms knights. Now are you
As safe as the Emperor.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: My alms knights! Nay, th’ are yours.
It is a shame for you, and I’ll stand too ’t;
Your foolish alms maintains more vagabonds,
Than all the noblemen in Kent beside.
Out, you rogues, you knaves! Work for your livings!—
Alas, poor men! O Lord, they may beg their hearts out,
There’s no more charity amongst men than amongst
So many mastiff dogs!—What make you here,
You needy knaves? Away, away, you villains.

speech.speaker: 2. SOLD.
speech.line: I beseech you, sir, be good to us.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Nay, nay, they know thee well enough. I think that all the beggars in this land are thy acquaintance. Go bestow your alms; none will control you, sir.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: What should I give them? You are grown so beggarly, you have scarce a bit of bread to give at your door. You talk of your religion so long, that you have banished charity from amongst you. A man may make a flax shop in your kitchen chimneys, for any fire there is stirring.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: If thou wilt give them nothing, send them hence. Let them not stand here starving in the cold.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Who! I drive them hence? If I drive poor men from your door, I’ll be hanged. I know not what I may come to myself. Yea, God help you, poor knaves. You see the world, i’faith! Well, you had a mother. Well, God be with thee, good Lady. Thy soul’s at rest. She gave more in shirts and smocks to poor children, than you spend in your house, and you’d you live a beggar too.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Even the worst deed that ere my mother did was in relieving such a fool as thou.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Yea, yea, I am a fool still. With all your wit you will die a beggar; go too.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Go, you old fool; give the poor people something. Go in, poor men, into the inner court, and take such alms as there is to be had.

speech.speaker: 1. SOLD.
speech.line: God bless your honor.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Hang you, rogues, hang you, There’s nothing but misery amongst you; you fear no law, you.

speech.speaker: OLD MAN.
speech.line: God bless you, good master Rafe, God save your life; you are good to the poor still.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Lord Powis disguised as a beggar and shroud himself.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: What fellow’s yonder comes along the grove?
Few passengers there be that know this way:
Me thinks he stops as though he stayoud for me,
And meant to shroud himself amongst the bushes.
I know the Clergy hate me to the death,
And my religion gets me many foes:
And this may be some desperate rogue, suborned
To work me mischief.—As it pleaseth God!
If he come toward me, sure I’ll stay his coming—
Be he but one man—what so’er he be.
I have been well acquainted with that face.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Well met, my honorable lord and friend.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: You are welcome, sir, what ere you be;
But of this sudden, sir, I do not know you.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: I am one that wisheth well unto your honor;
My name is Powis, an old friend of yours.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My honorable lord, and worthy friend,
What makes your lordship thus alone in Kent,
And thus disguised in this strange attire?

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: My Lord, an unexpected accident
Hath at this time inforc’d me to these parts;
And thus it hapt:—Not yet full five days since,
Now at the last assize at Hereford,
It chanced that the lord Herbert and myself,
‘Mongst other things, discoursing at the table,
Did fall in speech about some certain points
Of Wickliffe’s doctrine ‘gainst the papacy
And the religion catholique, maintained
Through the most part of Europe at this day.
This wilful teasty lord stuck not to say
That Wickliffe was a knave, a schismatic,
His doctrine devilish and heretical,
And what soe’er he was maintained the same,
Was traitor both to God and to his country.
Being moved at his peremptory speech,
I told him some maintained those opinions,
Men, and truer subjects than lord Herbert was:
And he replying in comparisons,
Your name was urged, my lord, ‘gainst his challenge,
To be a perfect favorer of the truth.
And to be short, from words we fell to blows,
Our servants and our tenants taking parts—
Many on both sides hurt—and for an hour
The broil by no means could be pacified,
Until the Judges, rising from the bench,
Were in their persons forced to part the fray.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: I hope no man was violently slain.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Faith, none, I trust, but the lord Herbert’s self,
Who is in truth so dangerously hurt,
As it is doubted he can hardly scape.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: I am sorry, my good lord, of these ill news.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: This is the cause that drives me into Kent,
To shroud myself with you, so good a friend,
Until I hear how things do speed at home.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Your lordship is most welcome unto Cobham;
But I am very sorry, my good lord,
My name was brought in question in this matter,
Considering I have many enemies,
That threaten malice, and do lie in wait
To take advantage of the smallest thing.
But you are welcome: and repose your lordship,
And keep your self here secret in my house,
Until we hear how the lord Herbert speeds.
Here comes my man.
Sirra, what news?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Yonder’s one master Butler of the privy chamber, is sent unto you from the King.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: I pray God the lord Herbert be not dead,
And the King, hearing whither I am gone,
Hath sent for me.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Comfort your self my lord, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Fellow, what ails thee? Doost thou quake? Dost thou shake? Dost thou tremble? Ha?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Peace, you old fool! Sirra, convey this gentleman in the back way, and bring the other into the walk.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Come, sir; you are welcome, if you love my lord.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: God have mercy, gentle friend.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: I thought as much: that it would not be long,
Before I heard of something from the King
About this matter.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Sir, yonder my lord walks, you see him;
I’ll have your men into the Cellar the while.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Welcome, good master Butler.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Thanks, my good lord: his Majesty doth commend
His love unto your lordship,
And wills you to repair unto the court.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: God bless his Highness, and confound his enemies!
I hope his Majesty is well.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: In health, my lord.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: God long continue it! Me thinks you look
As though you were not well: what ails you, sir?

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Faith, I have had a foolish odd mischance,
That angers me: coming over Shooters hill,
There came a fellow to me like a Sailor,
And asked me money; and whilst I stayoud my horse
To draw my purse, he takes th’ advantage of
A little bank and leaps behind me, whips
My purse away, and with a sudden jerk,
I know not how, threw me at least three yards
Out of my saddle. I never was so robbed
In all my life.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: I am very sorry, sir, for your mischance. We will send our warrant forth, to stay such suspicious persons as shall be found. Then, master Butler, we will attend you.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: I humbly thank your lordship, I will attend you.

scene.scenelocation: Kent. An outer court before Lord Cobham’s house.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I have the law to warrant what I do; and though the Lord Cobham be a noble man, that dispenses not with law. I dare serve process were a five noble men. Though we Sumners make sometimes a mad slip in a corner with a pretty wench, a Sumner must not go always by seeing: a man may be content to hide his eyous, where he may feel his profit. Well, this is my Lord Cobham’s house if I can devise to speak with him. If not, I’ll clap my citation upon’s door: so my lord of Rochester bid me. But me thinks here comes one of his men.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Welcome, good fellow, welcome; who wouldst thou speak with?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: With my lord Cobham I would speak, if thou be one of his men.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Yes, I am one of his men, but thou canst not speak with my lord.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: May I send to him then?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: I’ll tell thee that, when I know thy errand.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I will not tell my errand to thee.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Then keep it to thy self, and walk like a knave as thou camest.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I tell thee, my lord keeps no knaves, sirra.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Then thou servest him not, I believe: what lord is thy master?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: My lord of Rochester.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: In good time! And what wouldst thou have with my lord Cobham?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I come, by virtue of a process, to ascite him to appear before my lord in the court at Rochester.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Well, God grant me patience! I could eat this
conger. My lord is not at home; therefore it were good,
Sumner, you carried your process back.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: Why, if he will not be spoken withal, then will I leave it here; and see you that he take knowledge of it.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Swounds, you slave, do you set up your bills here! Go to;
take it down again. Doest thou know what thou dost?
Dost thou know on whom thou servest process?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: Yes, marry, do I; Sir John Oldcastle, Lord Cobham.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: I am glad thou knowest him yet. And, sirra, dost not thou know, that the lord Cobham is a brave lord, that keeps good beef and beer in his house, and every day feeds a hundred poor people at’s gate, and keeps a hundred tall fellows?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: What’s that to my process?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Marry, this, sir! Is this process parchment?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: Yes, marry.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: And this seal wax?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: It is so.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: If this be parchment, and this wax, eat you this parchment and this wax, or I will make parchment of your skin, and beat your brains into wax. Sirra Sumner, dispatch. Devour, sirra, devour.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I am my lord of Rochester’s Sumner; I came to do my office, and thou shalt answer it.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Sirra, no railing, but betake you to your teeth. Thou shalt eat no worse than thou bringst with thee: thou bringst it for my lord, and wilt thou bring my lord worse than thou wilt eat thy self?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: Sirra, I brought it not my lord to eat.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: O, do you sir me now? All’s one for that: but I’ll make you eat it, for bringing it.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I cannot eat it.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Can you not? S’blood I’ll beat you until you have a stomach.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: O hold, hold, good master servingman! I will eat it.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Be champing, be chawing, sir. Or I’ll chaw you, you rogue! The purest of the honey! Tough wax is the purest of the honey.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: O Lord, sir! Oh! Oh!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Feed, feed! Wholesome, rogue, wholesome! Cannot you, like an honest Sumner, walk with the devil your brother, to fetch in your Bailiffs’ rents, but you must come to a noble man’s house with process? S’blood! If thy seal were as broad as the lead that covers Rochester church, thou shouldst eat it.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: O, I am almost choked! I am almost choked!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Who’s within there? Will you shame my Lord? Is there no beer in the house? Butler! I say.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Here, here.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Give him beer.
There; tough old sheepskin’s bare, dry meat.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: O sir, let me go no further; I’ll eat my word.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Yea, marry, sit! So I mean: you shall eat more than your own word, for I’ll make you eat all the words in the process. Why, you drab monger, cannot the secrets of all the wenches in a shire serve your turn, but you must come hither with a citation? With a pox! I’ll cite you.
A cup of sack for the Sumner.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Here, sir, here.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Here, slave, I drink to thee.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: I thank you, sir.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Now if thou findst thy stomach well—because thou shalt see my Lord keep’s meat in’s house—if thou wilt go in, thou shalt have a piece of beef to the breakfast.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: No, I am very well, good master servingman, I thank you. Very well, sir.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: I am glad on’t. Then be walking towards Rochester to keep your stomach warm. And Sumner, if I may know you disturb a good wench within this Diocese If I do not make thee eat her petticoat, if there were four yards of Kentish cloth in’t, I am a villain.

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: God be with you, master servingman.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Farewell, Sumner.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: God save you Master Harpoole.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Welcome, Constable, welcome, Constable. What news with thee?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: And’t please you, Master Harpoole, I am to make hue and cry, for a fellow with one eyou that has robbed two clothiers, and am to crave your hindrance, for to search all suspected places; and they say there was a woman in the company.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Hast thou been at the alehouse? Hast thou sought there?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: I durst not search, sir, in my Lord Cobham’s liberty. Except I had some of his servants, which are for my warrant.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: An honest constable! An honest constable! Call forth him that keeps the alehouse here.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Ho! Who’s within there?

speech.speaker: ALE.
speech.line: Who calls there? Come near a God’s name! Oh, is’t you, Master Constable and Master Harpoole? You are welcome with all my heart. What make you here so early this morning?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Sirra, what strangers do you lodge? There is a robbery done this morning, and we are to search for all suspected persons.

speech.speaker: ALE.
speech.line: God’s bores! I am sorry for’t: i’faith, sir, I lodge no body but a good honest merry priest,—they call him Sir John of Wrotham— and a handsome woman that is his niece, that he says he has some suit in law for; and as they go up and down to London, sometimes they lie at my house.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: What, is he here in thy house now?

speech.speaker: ALE.
speech.line: She is, sir. I promise you, sir, he is a quiet man; and because he will not trouble too many rooms, he makes the woman lie every night at his bed’s feet.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Bring her forth! Constable, bring her forth! Let’s see her, let’s see her.

speech.speaker: ALE.
speech.line: Dorothy, you must come down to Master Constable.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Anon, forsooth.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Welcome, sweet lass, welcome.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I thank you, good Master servingman, and master Constable also.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: A plump girl by the mass, a plump girl! Ha, Doll, ha!
Wilt thou forsake the priest, and go with me?

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Ah! Well said, Master Harpoole. You are a merry old man, i’faith. I’faith, you will never be old. Now, by the mack, a pretty wench indeed!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Ye old mad merry Constable, art thou advised of that. Ha, well said, Doll! Fill some ale here.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Oh, if I wist this old priest would not stick to me, by Jove, I would ingle this old servingman.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Oh you old mad colt! I’faith, I’ll feak you! Fill all the pots in the house there.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Oh, well said, Master Harpoole! You are heart of oak when all’s done.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Ha, Doll, thou hast a sweet pair of lips, by the mass.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Truly you are a most sweet old man, as ever I saw. By my troth, you have a face able to make any woman in love with you.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Fill, sweet Doll; I’ll drink to thee.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: ’I pledge you, sir, and thank you therefore,
And I pray you let it come.’

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Doll, canst thou love me? A mad merry lass! Would to God I had never seen thee!

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I warrant you, you will not out of my thoughts this twelvemonth. Truly you are as full of favor, as a man may be. Ah, these sweet grey locks! By my troth, they are most lovely.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: God boores, master Harpoole, I will have one buss too.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: No licking for you, Constable! Hand off, hand off!

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: B’your lady, I love kissing as well as you.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Oh, you are an odd boy. You have a wanton eyou of your own! Ah, you sweet sugar lipped wanton, you will win as many women’s hearts as come in your company.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Doll, come hither.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Priest, she shall not.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I’ll come anon, sweet love.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Hand off, old fornicator.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Vicar, I’ll sit here in spite of thee. Is this fit stuff for a priest to carry up and down with him?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Ah, sirra, dost thou not know that a good fellow parson may have a chapel of ease, where his parish church is far off?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: You whoreson stoned Vicar!

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: You old stale ruffin! You lion of Cotswold!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: S’wounds, Vicar, I’ll geld you!

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Keep the King’s peace!

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Murder! Murder! Murder!

speech.speaker: ALE.
speech.line: Hold! As you are men, hold! For God’s sake be quiet! Put up your weapons. You draw not in my house.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: You whoreson bawdy priest!

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: You old mutton monger!

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Hold, sir John, hold!

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I pray thee, sweet hear, be quiet. I was but sitting to drink a pot of ale with him, even as kind a man as ever I met with.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Thou art a thief, I warrant thee.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Then I am but as thou hast been in thy days. Let’s not be ashamed of our trade; the King has been a thief himself.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Come, be quiet. Hast thou sped?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I have, wench: here be crowns, i’faith.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Come, let’s be all friends then.

speech.speaker: CONST.
speech.line: Well said, mistress Dorothy, i’faith.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Thou art the maddest priest that ever I met with.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Give me thy hand, thou art as good a fellow. I am a singer, a drinker, a bencher, a wencher! I can say a mass, and kiss a lass! Faith, I have a parsonage, and because I would not be at too much charges, this wench serves me for a sexton.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Well said, mad priest, we’ll in and be friends.

scene.scenelocation: London. A room in the Axe Inn, without Bishop-gate.

stagedir.dir: Enter sir Roger Acton, master Bourne, master Beverly, and William Murley the brewer of Dunstable.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Now, master Murley, I am well assured
You know our arrant, and do like the cause,
Being a man affected as we are.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Mary, God dild you, dainty my dear! No master, good sir Roger Acton Knight, master Bourne, and master Beverly esquires, gentlemen, and justices of the peace—no master I, but plain William Murley, the brewer of Dunstable, your honest neighbor, and your friend, if you be men of my profession.

speech.speaker: BEV.
speech.line: Professed friends to Wickliffe, foes to Rome.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Hold by me, lad; lean upon that staff, good master
Beverly: all of a house. Say your mind, say your mind.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: You know our faction now is grown so great,
Throughout the realm, that it begins to smoke
Into the Clergy’s eyous, and the King’s ear.
High time it is that we were drawn to head,
Our general and officers appointed;
And wars, you wot, will ask great store of coin.
Able to strength our action with your purse,
You are elected for a colonel
Over a regiment of fifteen bands.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fue, paltry, paltry! In and out, to and fro! Be it more or less, upon occasion. Lord have mercy upon us, what a world is this! Sir Roger Acton, I am but a Dunstable man, a plain brewer, you know: will lusty Cavaliering captains, gentlemen, come at my calling, go at my bidding? Dainty my dear, they’ll do a god of wax, a horse or cheese, a prick and a pudding. No, no, you must appoint some lord, or knight at least, to that place.

speech.speaker: BOURNE.
speech.line: Why, master Murley, you shall be a Knight:
Were you not in election to be shrieve?
Have you not past all offices but that?
Have you not wealth to make your wife a lady?
I warrant you, my lord, our General
Bestows that honor on you at first sight.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Mary, God dild you, dainty my dear!
But tell me, who shall be our General?
Where’s the lord Cobham, Sir John Oldcastle,
That noble alms-giver, housekeeper, virtuous,
Religious gentleman? Come to me there, boys,
Come to me there!

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Why, who but he shall be our General?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: And shall he knight me, and make me colonel?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: My word for that: sir William Murley, knight.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fellow sir Roger Acton, knight, all fellows—I mean in arms—how strong are we? How many partners? Our enemies beside the King are might. Be it more or less upon occasion, reckon our force.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: There are of us, our friends, and followers,
Three thousand and three hundred at the least;
Of northern lads four thousand, beside horse;
From Kent there comes with Sir John Oldcastle
Seven thousand; then from London issue out,
Of masters, servants, strangers, prentices,
Forty odd thousands into Ficket field,
Where we appoint our special rendezvous.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fue, paltry, paltry, in and out, to and fro! Lord have mercy upon us, what a world is this! Where’s that ficket field, sir Roger?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Behind saint Giles in the field near Holborne.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Newgate, up Holborne, S. Giles in the field, and to Tiborne: an old saw. For the day, for the day?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: On Friday next, the fourteenth day of January.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Tyllie vallie, trust me never if I have any liking of that day! Fue, paltry, paltry! Friday, quoth a! Dismal day! Childermass day this year was Friday.

speech.speaker: BEV.
speech.line: Nay, master Murley, if you observe the days,
We make some question of your constancy.
All days are like to men resolved in right.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Say Amen, and say no more. But say, and hold, master Beverly. Friday next, and Ficket field, and William Murley, and his merry men shall be all one. I have half a score jades that draw my beer carts,
And every jade shall bear a knave,
And every knave shall wear a jack,
And every jack shall have a skull,
And every skull shall shew a spear,
And every spear shall kill a foe
At Ficket field, at Ficket field.
John and Tom, and Dick and Hodge,
And Rafe and Robin, William and George,
And all my knaves shall fight like men,
At Ficket field on Friday next.

speech.speaker: BOURNE.
speech.line: What sum of money mean you to disburse?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: It may be modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely I may bring five hundred pound.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Five hundred, man! Five thousand’s not enough!
A hundred thousand will not pay our men
Two months together. Either come prepared
Like a brave Knight, and martial Colonel,
In glittering gold, and gallant furniture,
Bringing in coin a cart load at he least,
And all your followers mounted on good horse,
Or never come disgraceful to us all.

speech.speaker: BEV.
speech.line: Perchance you may be chosen Treasurer.
Ten thousand pound’s the least that you can bring.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Paltry, paltry! In and out, to and fro, upon occasion I have ten thousand pound to spend, and ten too. And rather than the Bishop shall have his will of me for my conscience, it shall out all. Flame and flax, flame and flax! It was got with water and malt, and it shall fly with fire and gun powder. Sir Roger, a cart load of money till the axetree crack, myself and my men in Ficket field on Friday next. Remember my Knighthood, and my place. There’s my hand; I’ll be there.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: See what ambition may persuade men to,
In hope of honor he will spend himself.

speech.speaker: BOURNE.
speech.line: I never thought a Brewer half so rich.

speech.speaker: BEV.
speech.line: Was never bankerout Brewer yet but one,
With using too much malt, too little water.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: That’s no fault in brewers nowadays.
Come, away, about our business.

scene.scenelocation: An audience-chamber in the palace at Eltham.

stagedir.dir: Enter King Henry, Suffolk, Butler, and Oldcastle kneeling to the King.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Tis not enough, Lord Cobham, to submit;
You must forsake your gross opinion.
The Bishops find themselves much injured,
And though, for some good service you have done,
We for our part are pleased to pardon you,
Yet they will not so soon be satisfied.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, unto your Majesty,
Next unto my God, I owe my life:
And what is mine, either by nature’s gift,
Or fortune’s bounty, all is at your service.
But, for obedience to the Pope of Rome,
I owe him none, nor shall his shaveling priests
That are in England alter my belief.
If out of holy Scripture they can prove,
That I am in an error I will yield,
And gladly take instruction at their hands;
But otherwise, I do beseech your grace,
My conscience may not be encroached upon.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: We would be loath to press our subjects’ bodies,
Much less their souls, the dear redeemed part
Of him that is the ruler of us all;
Yet let me counsel you, that might command:
Do not presume to tempt them with ill words,
Nor suffer any meetings to be had
Within your house, but to the uttermost,
Disperse the flocks of this new gathering sect.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My liege, if any breathe, that dares come forth,
And say my life in any of these points
Deserves th’attaindor of ignoble thoughts,
Here stand I, craving no remorse at all,
But even the utmost rigor may be shown.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Let it suffice; we know your loyalty.
What have you there?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: A deed of clemency;
Your Highness’ pardon for Lord Powis’ life,
Which I did beg, and you, my noble Lord,
Of gracious favor did vouchsafe to grant.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: But yet it is not signed with our hand.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Not yet, my liege.

stagedir.dir: One ready with pen and ink.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: The fact, you say, was done,
Not of prepensed malice, but by chance.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Upon mine honor so, no otherwise.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: There is his pardon; bid him make amends,
And cleanse his soul to God for his offense.
What we remit, is but the body’s scourge—
How now, Lord Bishop?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Justice, dread Sovereign!
As thou art King, so grant I may have justice.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What means this exclamation? Let us know.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Ah, my good lord, the state’s abused,
And our decrees most shamefully profaned.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How? Or by whom?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Even by this heretic,
This Jew, this traitor to your majesty.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Prelate, thou liest, even in thy greasy maw,
Or whosoever twits me with the name
Of either traitor, or of heretic.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Forbear, I say: and, Bishop, shew the cause
From whence this late abuse hath been derived.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Thus, mighty King:—by general consent,
A messenger was sent to cite this Lord,
To make appearance in the consistory;
And coming to his house, a ruffian slave,
One of his daily followers, met the man,
Who, knowing him to be a parroter,
Assaults him first and after, in contempt
Of us and our proceedings, makes him cate
The written process, parchment, scale and all:
Whereby his master neither was brought forth,
Nor we but scorned for our authority.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: When was this done?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: At six o’clock this morning.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And when came you to court?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Last night, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: By this it seems, he is not guilty of it,
And you have done him wrong t’accuse him so.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: But it was done, my lord, by his appointment,
Or else his man durst ne’er have been so bold.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Or else you durst be bold to interrupt,
And fill our ears with frivolous complaints.
Is this the duty you do bear to us?
Was’t not sufficient we did pass our word
To send for him, but you, misdoubting it,
Or—which is worse—intending to forestall
Our regal power, must likewise summon him?
This savors of Ambition, not of zeal,
And rather proves you malice his estate,
Than any way that he offends the law.
Go to, we like it not; and he your officer,
That was employed so much amiss herein,
Had his desert for being insolent.
So, Cobham, when you please you may depart.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: I humbly bid farewell unto my liege.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Farewell.—What’s the news by Huntington?

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Sir Roger Acton and a crew, my Lord,
Of bold seditious rebels are in Arms,
Intending reformation of Religion.
And with their Army they intend to pitch
In Ficket field, unless they be repulsed.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: So near our presence? Dare they be so bold?
And will proud war, and eager thirst of blood,
Whom we had thought to entertain far off,
Press forth upon us in our native bounds?
Must we be forced to hansell our sharp blades
In England here, which we prepared for France?
Well, a God’s name be it! What’s their number, say,
Or who’s the chief commander of this rout?

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Their number is not known, as yet, my Lord,
But ‘tis reported Sir John Oldcastle
Is the chief man on whom they do depend.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How, the Lord Cobham?

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Yes, my gracious lord.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: I could have told your majesty as much
Before he went, but that I saw your Grace
Was too much blinded by his flattery.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Send post, my Lord, to fetch him back again.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Traitor unto his country, how he smoothed,
And seemed as innocent as Truth it self!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I cannot think it yet he would be false;
But if he be, no matter; let him go.
We’ll meet both him and them unto their woe.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: This falls out well, and at the last I hope
To see this heretic die in a rope.

scene.scenelocation: An avenue leading to Lord Cobham’s house in Kent.

stagedir.dir: Enter Earl of Cambridge, Lord Scroop, Gray, and Chartres the French factor.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: Once more, my Lord of Cambridge, make rehearsal,
How you do stand entitled to the Crown.
The deeper shall we print it in our minds,
And every man the better be resolved,
When he perceives his quarrel to be just.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Then thus, Lord Scroop, sir Thomas Gray, and you,
Monsieur de Chartres, agent for the French:—
This Lionel, Duke of Clarence, as I said,
Third son of Edward (England’s King) the third,
Had issue Phillip, his sole daughter and heir;
Which Phillip afterward was given in marriage
To Edmund Mortimer, the Earl of March,
And by him had a son called Roger Mortimer;
Which Roger, likewise, had of his descent
Edmund, Roger, Anne, and Eleanor—
Two daughters and two sons—but those three
Died without issue. Anne, that did survive,
And now was left her father’s only heir,
My fortune was to marry, being too
By my grandfather of Kind Edward’s line:
So of his sirname, I am called, you know,
Richard Plantagenet. My father was
Edward, the Duke of York, and son and heir
To Edmund Langley, Edward the third’s fifth son.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: So that it seems your claim comes by your wife,
As lawful heir to Roger Mortimer,
The son of Edmund, which did marry Phillip,
Daughter and heir to Lionel, Duke of Clarence.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: True, for this Harry and his father both,
Harry the first, as plainly doth appear,
Are false intruders and usurp the Crown.
For when young Richard was at Pomfret slain,
In him the title of prince Edward died,
That was the eldest of king Edward’s sons:
William, of Hatfield, and their second brother,
Death in his nonage had before bereft:
So that my wife, derived from Lionel,
Third son unto king Edward, ought proceed,
And take possession of the Diadem
Before this Harry, or his father king,
Who fetched their title but from Lancaster,
Forth of that royal line. And being thus,
What reason ist but she should have her right?

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: I am resolved our enterprise is just.

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: Harry shall die, or else resign his crown.

speech.speaker: CHART.
speech.line: Perform but that, and Charles, the king of France,
Shall aid you, lords, not only with his men,
But send you money to maintain your wars.
Five hundred thousand crowns he bade me profer,
If you can stop but Harry’s voyage for France.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: We never had a fitter time than now,
The realm in such division as it is.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Besides, you must persuade you, there is due
Vengeance for Richard’s murder, which, although
It be deferred, yet will it fall at last,
And now as likely as another time.
Sin hath had many years to ripen in,
And now the harvest cannot be far off,
Wherein the weeds of usurpation
Are to be cropped, and cast into the fire.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: No more, earl Cambridge; here I plight my faith,
To set up thee and thy renowned wife.

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: Gray will perform the same, as he is knight.

speech.speaker: CHART.
speech.line: And to assist you, as I said before,
Charters doth gage the honor of his king.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: We lack but now Lord Cobham’s fellowship,
And then our plot were absolute indeed.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Doubt not of him, my lord; his life’s pursued
By the incensed Clergy, and of late,
Brought in displeasure with the king, assures
He may be quickly won unto our faction.
Who hath the articles were drawn at large
Of our whole purpose?

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: That have I, my lord.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: We should not now be far off from his house;
Our serious conference hath beguiled the way.
See where his castle stands. Give me the writing.
When we are come unto the speech of him,
Because we will not stand to make recount,
Of that which hath been said, here he shall read
Our minds at large, and what we crave of him.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: A ready way. Here comes the man himself,
Booted and spurred; it seems he hath been riding.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Well met, lord Cobham.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My lord of Cambridge?
Your honor is most welcome into Kent,
And all the rest of this fair company.
I am new come from London, gentle Lords;
But will you not take Cowling for your host,
And see what entertainment it affords?

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: We were intended to have been your guests:
But now this lucky meeting shall suffice
To end our business, and defer that kindness.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Business, my lord? What business should you have
But to be merry? We have no delicates,
But this I’ll promise you: a piece of venison,
A cup of wine, and so forth—hunters’ fare;
And if you please, we’ll strike the stag our selves
Shall fill our dishes with his well-fed flesh.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: That is, indeed, the thing we all desire.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My lords and you shall have your choice with me.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Nay, but the stag which we desire to strike
Lives not in Cowling; if you will consent,
And go with us, we’ll bring you to a forest,
Where runs a lusty herd; amongst the which
There is a stag superior to the rest,
A stately beast that, when his fellows run,
He leads the race, and beats the sullen earth,
As though he scorned it, with his trampling hooves.
Aloft he bears his head, and with his breast,
Like a huge bulwark, counter-checks the wind:
And when he standeth still, he stretcheth forth
His proud ambitious neck, as if he meant
To wound the firmament with forked horns.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Tis pity such a goodly beast should die.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Not so, sir John, for he is tyrannous,
And gores the other deer, and will not keep
Within the limits are appointed him.
Of late he’s broke into a several,
Which doth belong to me, and there he spoils
Both corn and pasture. Two of his wild race,
Alike for stealth and covetous encroaching,
Already are removed; if he were dead,
I should not only be secure from hurt,
But with his body make a royal feast.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: How say you, then; will you first hunt with us?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Faith, Lords, I like the pastime; where’s the place>

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Peruse this writing; it will shew you all,
And what occasion we have for the sport.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Call you this hunting, my lords? Is this the stag
You fain would chase—Harry our dread king?
So we may make a banquet for the devil,
And in the stead of wholesome meat, prepare
A dish of poison to confound our selves.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Why so, lord Cobham? See you not our claim?
And how imperiously he holds the crown?

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: Besides, you know your self is in disgrace,
Held as a recreant, and pursued to death.
This will defend you from your enemies,
And stablish your religion through the land.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Notorious treason! Yet I will conceal
My secret thoughts, to sound the depth of it.
My lord of Cambridge, I do see your claim,
And what good may redound unto the land
By prosecuting of this enterprise.
But where are the men? Where’s power and furniture
To order such an action? We are weak;
Harry, you know’s a mighty potentate.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Tut, we are strong enough: you are beloved,
And many will be glad to follow you;
We are the like, and some will follow us.
Besides, there is hope from France: here’s an ambassador
That promiseth both men and money too.
The commons likewise (as we hear) pretend
A sudden tumult; we will join with them.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Some likelihood, I must confess, to speed;
But how shall I believe this is plain truth?
You are, my lords, such men as live in Court,
And highly have been favored of the king,
Especially lord Scroop, whom oftentimes
He maketh choice of for his bedfellow;
And you, lord Gray, are of his privy counsel:
Is not this a train to entrap my life?

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Then perish may my soul! What, think you so?

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: We’ll swear to you.

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: Or take the sacrament.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Nay, you are noble men, and I imagine,
As you are honorable by birth and blood,
So you will be in heart, in thought, in word.
I crave no other testimony but this:
That you would all subscribe, and set your hands
Unto this writing which you gave to me.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: With all our hearts. Who hath any pen and ink?

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: My pocket should have one: yea, here it is.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Give it me, lord Scroop.—There is my name.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: And there is my name.

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: And mine.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Sir, let me crave,
That you would likewise write your name with theirs,
For confirmation of your master’s word,
The king of France.

speech.speaker: CHART.
speech.line: That will I, noble lord.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: So now this action is well knit together,
And I am for you. Where’s our meeting, lords?

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Here, if you please, the tenth of July next.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: In Kent? Agreed: now let us in to supper.
I hope your honors will not away to night.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Yes, presently; for I have far to ride,
About soliciting of other friends.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: And we would not be absent from the court,
Lest thereby grow suspicion in the king.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Yet taste a cup of wine before you go.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Not now, my lord, we thank you: so farewell.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Farewell, my noble lords.—My noble lords?
My noble villains, base conspirators.
How can they look his Highness in the face,
Whom they so closely study to betray?
But I’ll not sleep until I make it known.
This head shall not be burdened with such thoughts,
Nor in this heart will I conceal a deed
Of such impiety against my king.
Madam, how now?

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: You are welcome home, my lord.
Why seem you so disquiet in your looks?
What hath befallen you that disquiets your mind?

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: Bad news, I am afraid, touching my husband.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Madam, not so: there is your husband’s pardon.
Long may you live, each joy unto the other.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: So great a kindness as i know not how
To make reply; my sense is quite confounded.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Let that alone: and madam, stay me not,
For I must back unto the court again
With all the speed I can. Harpoole, my horse.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: So soon, my Lord? What, will you ride all night?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: All night or day; it must be so, sweet wife.
Urge me not why or what my business is,
But get you in. Lord Powis, bear with me,
And madam, think your welcome ne’er the worse:
My house is at your use. Harpoole, away.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Shall I attend your lordship to the court?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Yes, sir; your gelding! Mount you presently.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: I prithee, Harpoole, look unto thy lord.
I do not like this sudden posting back.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Some earnest business is a foot belike;
What e’er it be, pray God be his good guide.

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: Amen! That hath so highly us bested.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: Come, madam, and my lord, we’ll hope the best;
You shall not into Wales till he return.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Though great occasion be we should depart,
Yet madam will we stay to be resolved
Of this unlooked for, doubtful accident.

scene.scenelocation: A road near Highgate.

stagedir.dir: Enter Murley and his men, prepared in some filthy order for war.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Come, my hearts of flint, modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely, no man afore his Leader; follow your master, your Captain, your Knight that shall be, for the honor of Meal-men, Millers, and Malt-men. Dunne is the mouse. Dick and tom, for the credit of Dunstable, ding down the enemy to morrow; you shall not come into the field like beggars. Where be Leonard and Laurence, my two loaders? Lord have mercy upon us, what a world is this? I would give a couple of shillings for a dozen of good feathers for you, and forty pence for as many scarfs to set you out withal. Frost and snow! A man has no heart to fight till he be brave.

speech.speaker: DICK.
speech.line: Master, I hope we be no babes. For our manhood, our bucklers and our town foot-balls can bear witness: and this light parrel we have shall off, and we’ll fight naked afore we run away.

speech.speaker: TOM.
speech.line: Nay, I am of Laurence mind for that, for he means to leave his life behind him; he and Leonard, your two loaders, are making their wills because they have wives. Now we bachelors bid our friends scramble for our goods if we die: but, master, pray you, let me ride upon Cutte.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Meal and salt, wheat and malt, fire and tow, frost and snow! Why, Tom, thou shalt. Let me see: here are you, William and George are with my cart, and Robin and Hodge holding my own two horses: proper men, handsome men, tall men, true men.

speech.speaker: DICK.
speech.line: But, master, master, me thinks you are a mad man to hazard your own person and a cart load of money too.

speech.speaker: TOM.
speech.line: Yea, and, master, there’s a worse matter in’t. If it be as I heard say, we go to fight against all the learned Bishops, that should give us their blessing; and if they curse us, we shall speed ne’er the better.

speech.speaker: DICK.
speech.line: Nay, bir lady, some say the King takes their part; and, master, dare you fight against the King?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fie, paltry, paltry! In and out, to and fro, upon occasion; if the King be so unwise to come there, we’ll fight with him too.

speech.speaker: TOM.
speech.line: What, if you should kill the King?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Then we’ll make another.

speech.speaker: DICK.
speech.line: Is that all? Do you not speak treason?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: If we do, who dare trip us? We come to fight for our conscience, and for honor. Little know you what is in my bosom. Look here, mad knaves, a pair of gilt spurs.

speech.speaker: TOM.
speech.line: A pair of golden spurs? Why do you not put them on your heels? Your bosom’s no place for spurs.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Be’t more or less upon occasion, Lord have mercy upon us, Tom, th’art a fool, and thou speakest treason to knighthood. Dare any wear golden or silver spurs till he be a knight? No, I shall be knighted tomorrow, and then they shall on. Sirs, was it ever read in the church book of Dunstable, that ever malt man was made knight?

speech.speaker: TOM.
speech.line: No, but you are more. You are meal-man, maltman, miller, corn-master and all.

speech.speaker: DICK.
speech.line: Yea, and half a brewer too, and the devil and all for wealth.
You bring more money with you, than all the rest.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: The more’s my honor. I shall be a knight to morrow! Let me spose my men: Tom upon cut, Dick upon hob, Hodge upon Ball, Raph upon Sorell, and Robin upon the forehorse.

speech.speaker: TOM.
speech.line: Stand, who comes there?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: All friends, good fellow.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Friends and fellows, indeed, sir Roger.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Why, thus you shew your self a Gentleman,
To keep your day, and come so well prepared.
Your cart stands yonder, guarded by your men,
Who tell me it is loaden with coin.
What sum is there?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Ten thousand pound, sir Roger: and modestly, decently, soberly, and handsomely, see what I have here against I be knighted.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Gilt spurs? ‘tis well.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: But where’s your army, sir?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Dispersed in sundry villages about:
Some here with us in Highgate, some at Finchley,
Totnam, Enfield, Edmunton, Newington,
Islington, Hogsdon, Pancredge, Kensington;
Some nearer Thames, Ratcliffe, Blackwall and Bow;
But our chief strength must be the Londoners,
Which, ere the Sun to morrow shine,
Will be near fifty thousand in the field.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Mary, God dild you, dainty my dear! But upon occasion, sir Roger Acton, doth not the King know of it, and gather his power against us?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: No, he’s secure at Eltham.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: What do the Clergy?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Fear extremely, yet prepare no force.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: In and out, to and fro, Bully my boikin, we shall carry the world afore us! I vow by my worship, when I am knighted, we’ll take the King napping, if he stand on their part.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: This night we few in Highgate will repose.
With the first cock we’ll rise and arm our selves,
To be in Ficket field by break of day,
And there expect our General.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Sir John Oldcastle? What if he come not?

speech.speaker: BOURNE.
speech.line: Yet our action stands.
Sir Roger Acton may supply his place.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: True, Master Bourne, but who shall make me knight?

speech.speaker: BEV.
speech.line: He that hath power to be our General.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Talk not of trifles; come, let’s away.
Our friends of London long till it be day.

scene.scenelocation: A high road in Kent.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir John of Wrotham and Doll.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: By my troth, thou art as jealous a man as lives.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Canst thou blame me, Doll? Thou art my lands, my goods, my jewels, my wealth, my purse. None walks within forty miles of London, but a plies thee as truly as the parish does the poor man’s box.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I am as true to thee as the stone is in the wall; and thou knowest well enough, sir John, I was in as good doing, when I came to thee, as any wench need to be; and therefore thou hast tried me, that thou hast: by God’s body, I will not be kept as I have been, that I will not.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Doll, if this blade hold, there’s not a peddler walks with a pack, but thou shalt as boldly choose of his wares, as with thy ready money in a Merchant’s shop. We’ll have as good silver as the King coins any.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: What, is all the gold spent you took the last day from the
Courtier?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Tis gone, Doll, ‘tis flown; merely come, merely gone: he comes a horse back that much pay for all. We’ll have as good meat as money can get, and as good gowns as can be bought for gold. Be merry, wench, the malt-man comes on Monday.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: You might have left me at Cobham, until you had been better provided for.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: No, sweet Doll, no: I do not like that. Yond old ruffian is not for the priest: I do not like a new clerk should come in the old belfry.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Ah, thou art a mad priest, i’faith.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Come, Doll; I’ll see thee safe at some alehouse here at Cray, and the next sheep that comes shall leave his fleece.

scene.scenelocation: Blackheath.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: Enter the King, Suffolk and Butler.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: My lord of Suffolk, post away for life,
And let our forces of such horse and foot,
As can be gathered up by any means,
Make speedy rendezvous in Tuttle fields.
It must be done this evening, my Lord;
This night the rebels mean to draw to head
Near Islington, which if your speed prevent not,
If once they should unite their several forces,
Their power is almost thought invincible.
Away, my Lord; I will be with you soon.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: I go, my Sovereign, with all happy speed.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Make haste, my lord of Suffolk, as you love us.
Butler, post you to London with all speed;
Command the Mayor and shrieves, on their allegiance,
The city gates be presently shut up
And guarded with a strong sufficient watch,
And not a man be suffered to pass
Without a special warrant from our self.
Command the Postern by the Tower be kept,
And proclamation, on the pain of death,
That not a citizen stir from his doors,
Except such as the Mayor and Shrieves shall choose
For their own guard and safety of their persons.
Butler, away; have care unto my charge.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: I go, my Sovereign.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Butler!

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: My lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Go down by Greenwich, and command a boat
At the Friar’s bridge attend my coming down.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: I will, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: It’s time, I think, to look unto rebellion,
When Acton doth expect unto his aid
No less than fifty thousand Londoners.
Well, I’ll to Westminster in this disguise,
To hear what news is stirring in these brawls.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Stand, true man! Says a thief.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Stand, thief! Says a true man. How if a thief?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Stand, thief, too.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then, thief or true-man, I see I must stand. I see, how soever the world wags, the trade of thieving yet will never down. What art thou?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: A good fellow.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: So am I too. I see thou dost know me.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: If thou be a good fellow, play the good fellow’s part: deliver thy purse without more ado.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I have no money.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I must make you find some before we part. If you have no money, you shall have war: as many sound dry blows as your skin can carry.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is that the plain truth?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Sirra, no more ado. Come, come, give me the money you have. Dispatch, I cannot stand all day.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Well, if thou wilt needs have it, there ‘tis: just the proverb, one thief robs another. Where the devil are all my old thieves, that were wont to keep this walk? Falstaff, the villain, is so fat, he cannot get on’s horse, but me thinks Poines and Peto should be stirring here about.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: How much is there on’t, of thy word?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: A hundred pound in Angels, on my word.
The time has been I would have done as much
For thee, if thou hadst past this way, as I have now.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Sirra, what art thou? Thou seem’st a gentleman.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I am no less; yet a poor one now, for thou hast all my money.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: From whence cam’st thou?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: From the court at Eltham.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Art thou one of the King’s servants?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yes, that I am, and one of his chamber.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I am glad thou art no worse. Thou mayoust the better spare thy money. And thinkst thou thou mightst get a poor thief his pardon, if he should have need.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yes, that I can.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Wilt thou do so much for me, when I shall have occasion?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yes, faith will I, so it be for no murder.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
