speech.line: Nay, I am a pitiful thief. All the hurt I do a man, I take but his purse. I’ll kill no man.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then, of my word, I’ll do it.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Give me thy hand of the same.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: There ‘tis.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Methinks the King should be good to thieves, because he has been a thief himself, though I think now he be turned true man.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Faith, I have heard indeed he has had an ill name that way in his yeth; but how canst thou tell he has been a thief?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: How? Because he once robbed me before I fell to the trade myself. When that foul villainous guts, that led him to all that rogery, was in’s company there, that Falstaff.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Well, if he did rob thee then, thou art but even with him now, I’ll be sworn.—Thou knowest not the king now, I think, if thou sawest him?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Not I, i’faith.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: So it should seem.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Well, if old King Henry had lived, this King that is now had made thieving the best trade in England.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why so?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Because he was the chief warden of our company. It’s pity that e’er he should have been a King; he was so brave a thief. But, sirra, wilt remember my pardon if need be?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yes, faith, will I.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Wilt thou? Well then, because thou shalt go safe—for thou mayoust hap (being so early) be met with again before thou come to Southwark—if any man, when he should bid thee good morrow, bid thee stand, say thou but Sir John, and he will let thee pass.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is that the word? Well, then, let me alone.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Nay, sirra, because I think indeed I shall have some occasion to use thee, and as thou comest oft this way, I may light on thee another time not knowing thee, here! I’ll break this Angel. Take thou half of it; this is a token betwixt thee and me.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: God have mercy; farewell.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: O my fine golden slaves! Here’s for thee, wench, i’faith. Now, Doll, we will revel in our bower! This is a tithe pig of my vicarage. God have mercy, neighbor Shooters hill; you paid your tithe honestly. Well, I hear there is a company of rebels up against the King, got together in Ficket field near Holborne, and as it is thought here in Kent, the King will be there to night in’s own person; well, I’ll to the King’s camp, and it shall go hard, but, if there be any doings, I’ll make some good boot amongst them.

scene.scenelocation: A field near London. King Henry’s camp.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: Enter King Henry in disguise, Suffolk, Huntington, and two with lights.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: My lords of Suffolk and of Huntington,
Who scouts it now? Or who stands Sentinels?
What men of worth? What Lords do walk the round?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: May it please your Highness—

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Peace, no more of that.
The King’s asleep; wake not his majesty
With terms nor titles; he’s at rest in bed.
Kings do not use to watch themselves; they sleep,
And let rebellion and conspiracy
Revel and havoc in the common wealth.—
Is London looked unto?

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: It is, my Lord:
Your noble Uncle Exeter is there,
Your brother Gloucester and my Lord of Warwick,
Who, with the mayor and the Aldermen,
Do guard the gates, and keep good rule within;
The Earl of Cambridge and sir Thomas Gray
Do walk the Round; Lord Scroop and Butler scout.
So, though it please your majesty to jest,
Were you in bed, well might you take your rest.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I thank you, Lords, but you do know of old,
That I have been a perfect night-walker.
London, you say, is safely looked unto—
Alas, poor rebels, there your aid must fail—
And the Lord Cobham, Sir John Oldcastle,
He’s quiet in Kent. Acton, you are deceived;
Reckon again, you count without your host;
To morrow you shall give account to us.
Til when, my friends, this long cold winter’s night
How can we spend? King Harry is a sleep
And all his Lords, these garments tell us so;
All friends at football, fellows all in field,
Harry, and Dick, and George. Bring us a drum;
Give us square dice, we’ll keep this court of guard
For all good fellows companies that come.
Where’s that mad priest you told me was in Arms,
To fight, as well as pray, if need required?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: He’s in the Camp, and if he know of this,
I undertake he would not be long hence.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Trip, Dick. Trip, George.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: I must have the dice.
What do we play at?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Passage, if you please.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Set round then; so, at all.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: George, you are out.
Give me the dice. I pass for twenty pound.
Here’s to our lucky passage into France.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Harry, you pass indeed, for you sweep all.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: A sign king Harry shall sweep all in France.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Edge you, good fellows; take a fresh gamester in.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Master Parson? We play nothing but gold.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: And, fellow, I tell thee that the priest hath gold. Gold? S’blood, you are but beggarly soldiers to me. I think I have more gold than all you three.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: It may be so, but we believe it not.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Set, priest, set. I pass for all that gold.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Ye pass, indeed.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Priest, hast thou any more?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Zounds, what a question’s that?
I tell thee I have more than all you three.
At these ten Angels!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I wonder how thou comest by all this gold;
How many benefices hast thou, priest?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I’faith, but one. Dost wonder how I come by gold? I wonder rather how poor soldiers should have gold; for I’ll tell thee, good fellow: we have every day tithes, offerings, christenings, weddings, burials; and you poor snakes come seldom to a booty. I’ll speak a proud word: I have but one parsonage, Wrotham; ‘tis better than the Bishopric of Rochester. There’s ne’er a hill, heath, nor down in all Kent, but ‘tis in my parish: Barham down, Chobham down, Gad’s Hill, Wrotham hill, Black heath, Cock’s heath, Birchen wood, all pay me tithe. Gold, quotha? You pass not for that.

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Harry, you are out. Now, parson, shake the dice.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Set, set; I’ll cover you at all. A plague on’t, I am out. The devil, and dice, and a wench, who will trust them?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Sayoust thou so, priest? Set fair; at all for once.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Out, sir; pay all.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: S’blood, pay me angel gold.
I’ll none of your cracked French crowns nor pistolets.
Pay me fair angel gold, as I pay you.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No cracked French crowns? I hope to see more cracked
French crowns ere long.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Thou meanest of French men’s crowns, when the King is in France.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Set round, at all.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Pay all: this is some luck.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Give me the dice, ‘tis I must shred the priest:
At all, sir John.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: The devil and all is yours. At that! S’death, what casting is this?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: Well thrown, Harry, i’faith.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I’ll cast better yet.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Then I’ll be hanged. Sirra, hast thou not given thy soul to the devil for casting?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I pass for all.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Thou passest all that e’er I played withal.
Sirra, dost thou not cog, nor foist, nor slur?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Set, parson, set; the dice die in my hand:
When parson, when? What, can you find no more?
Already dry? Wast you bragged of your store?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: All’s gone but that.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: What? Half a broken angel?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Why sir, ‘tis gold.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Yea, and I’ll cover it.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: The devil do you good on’t, I am blind, you have blown me up.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Nay, tarry, priest. You shall not leave us yet.
Do not these pieces fit each other well?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: What if they do?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thereby begins a tale:
There was a thief, in face much like Sir John—
But twas not he, that thief was all in green—
Met me last day at Black Heath, near the park,
With him a woman. I was all alone
And weaponless, my boy had all my tools,
And was before providing me a boat.
Short tale to make, Sir John—the thief, I mean—
Took a just hundred pound in gold from me.
I stormed at it, and swore to be revenged
If e’er we met. He, like a lusty thief,
Brake with his teeth this angel just in two
To be a token at our meeting next,
Provided I should charge no officer
To apprehend him, but at weapon’s point
Recover that and what he had beside.
Well met, Sir John; betake you to your tools
By torch light, for, master parson, you are he
That had my gold.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Zounds, I won ’t in play, in fair square play, of the keeper of Eltham park. And that I will maintain with this poor whinyard, be you two honest men to stand and look upon’s, and let’s alone, and take neither part.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Agreed! I charge you do not budget a foot.
Sir John, have at you.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Soldier, ware your sconce.

stagedir.dir: Here, as they are ready to strike, enter Butler and draws his weapon and steps betwixt them.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Hold, villains, hold! My Lords, what do you mean,
To see a traitor draw against the King?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: The King! God’s will, I am in a proper pickle.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Butler, what news? Why dost thou trouble us?

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Please it your Highness, it is break of day,
And as I scouted near to Islington,
The gray eyed morning gave me glimmering
Of armed men coming down Highgate hill,
Who by their course are coasting hitherward.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Let us withdraw, my Lords. Prepare our troops
To charge the rebels, if there be such cause.
For this lewd priest, this devilish hypocrite,
That is a thief, a gamester, and what not,
Let him be hanged up for example sake.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Not so my gracious sovereign. I confess that I am a frail man, flesh and blood as other are: but, set my imperfections aside, by this light, you have not a taller man, nor a truer subject to the Crown and State, than Sir John of Wrotham.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Will a true subject rob his King?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Alas, twas ignorance and want, my gracious liege.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Twas want of grace. Why, you should be as salt
To season others with good document,
Your lives as lamps to give the people light,
As shepherds, not as wolves to spoil the flock.
Go hang him, Butler.

speech.speaker: BUT.
speech.line: Didst thou not rob me?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I must confess I saw some of your gold. But, my dread Lord, I am in no humor for death; therefore, save my life. God will that sinners live; do not you cause me die. Once in their lives the best may go astray, and if the world say true, your self (my liege) have been a thief.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I confess I have,
But I repent and have reclaimed myself.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: So will I do, if you will give me time.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Wilt thou? My lords, will you be his sureties?

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: That when he robs again, he shall be hanged.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I ask no more.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And we will grant thee that.
Live and repent, and prove an honest man,
Which when I hear, and safe return from France,
I’ll give thee living: till then take thy gold;
But spend it better than at cards or wine,
For better virtues fit that coat of thine.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Vivat Rex and curat lex! My liege, if you have cause of battle, you shall see Sir John of Wrotham bestir himself in your quarrel.

scene.scenelocation: A field of Battle near London.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: After an alarum enter Harry, Suffolk, Huntington, Sir John, bringing forth Acton, Beverley, and Murley prisoners.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Bring in those traitors, whose aspiring minds
Thought to have triumph’d in our overthrow.
But now you see, base villains, what success
Attends ill actions wrongfully attempted.
Sir Roger Acton, thou retainst the name
Of knight, and shouldst be more discreetly tempered,
Than join with peasants: gentry is divine,
But thou hast made it more than popular.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Pardon, my Lord; my conscience urged me to it.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thy conscience? Then thy conscience is corrupt,
For in thy conscience thou art bound to us,
And in thy conscience thou shouldst love thy country;
Else what’s the difference twixt a Christian
And the uncivil manners of the Turk?

speech.speaker: BEV.
speech.line: We meant no hurt unto your majesty,
But reformation of Religion.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Reform Religion? Was it that you sought?
I pray who gave you that authority?
Belike, then, we do hold the scepter up
And sit within the throne but for a cipher.
Time was, good subjects would make known their grief
And pray amendment, not enforce the same,
Unless their King were tyrant, which I hope
You cannot justly say that Harry is.
What is that other?

speech.speaker: SUFF.
speech.line: A malt-man, my Lord,
And dwelling in Dunstable as he says.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Sirra, what made you leave your barley broth,
To come in armor thus against your King?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fie, paltry, paltry; to and fro, in and out upon occasion; what a world’s this! Knight-hood (my liege) twas knight-hood brought me hither. They told me I had wealth enough to make my wife a lady.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And so you brought those horses which we saw,
Trapped all in costly furniture, and meant
To wear these spurs when you were knighted once?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: In and out upon occasion, I did.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: In and out upon occasion, therefore,
You shall be handed, and in the stead of wearing
These spurs upon your heels, about your neck
They shall bewray your folly to the world.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: In and out upon occasion, that goes hard.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fie, paltry, paltry, to and fro; good my liege, a pardon. I am sorry for my fault.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: That comes too late: but tell me, went there none
Beside sir Roger Acton, upon whom
You did depend to be your governor?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: None, none, my Lord, but Sir John Oldcastle.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Bears he part in this conspiracy?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: We looked, my Lord, that he would meet us here.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: But did he promise you that he would come?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Such letters we received forth of Kent.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Where is my Lord the King?—Health to your grace.
Examining, my Lord, some of these caitive rebels,
It is a general voice amongst them all,
That they had never come unto this place,
But to have met their valiant general,
The good Lord Cobham, as they title him:
Whereby, my Lord, your grace may now perceive,
His treason is apparent, which before
He sought to color by his flattery.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Now, by my royalty, I would have sworn
But for his conscience, which I bear withal,
There had not lived a more true hearted subject.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: It is but counterfeit, my gracious lord,
And therefore, may it please your majesty
To set your hand unto this precept here,
By which we’ll cause him forthwith to appear,
And answer this by order of the law.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Bishop, not only that, but take commission
To search, attach, imprison, and condemn
This most notorious traitor as you please.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: It shall be done, my Lord, without delay.—
So now I hold, Lord Cobham, in my hand,
That which shall finish thy disdained life.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: I think the iron age begins but now,
(Which learned poets have so often taught)
Wherein there is no credit to be given,
To either words, or looks, or solemn oaths.
For if there were, how often hath he sworn,
How gently tuned the music of his tongue,
And with what amiable face beheld he me,
When all, God knows, was but hypocricy.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Long life and prosperous reign unto my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Ah, villain, canst thou wish prosperity,
Whose heart includeth naught but treachery?
I do arrest thee here myself, false knight,
Of treason capital against the state.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Of treason, mighty prince? Your grace mistakes.
I hope it is but in the way of mirth.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Thy neck shall feel it is in earnest shortly.
Darst thou intrude into our presence, knowing
How heinously thou hast offended us?
But this is thy accustomed deceit;
Now thou perceivest thy purpose is in vain,
With some excuse or other thou wilt come,
To clear thy self of this rebellion.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Rebellion, good my Lord? I know of none.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: If you deny it, here is evidence.
See you these men? You never counseled,
Nor offered them assistance in their wars?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Speak, sirs. Not one but all; I crave no favor.
Have ever I been conversant with you,
Or written letters to encourage you,
Or kindled but the least or smallest part
Of this your late unnatural rebellion?
Speak, for I dare the uttermost you can.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: In and out upon occasion, I know you not.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: No? Didst not say that Sir John Oldcastle
Was one with whom you purposed to have met?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: True, I did say so, but in what respect?
Because I heard it was reported so.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Was there no other argument but that?

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: To clear my conscience ere I die, my lord,
I must confess, we have no other ground
But only rumor, to accuse this lord,
Which now I see was merely fabulous.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: The more pernicious you to taint him then,
Whom you knew not was faulty, yea or no.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Let this, my Lord, which I present your grace,
Speak for my loyalty: read these articles,
And then give sentence of my life or death.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Earl Cambridge, Scroop, and Gray corrupted
With bribes from Charles of France, either to win
My Crown from me, or secretly contrive
My death by treason? Is this possible?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: There is the platform, and their hands, my lord,
Each severally subscribed to the same.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Oh never heard of, base ingratitude!
Even those I hug within my bosom most
Are readiest evermore to sting my heart.
Pardon me, Cobham, I have done thee wrong;
Hereafter I will live to make amends.
Is, then, their time of meeting no near hand?
We’ll meet with them, but little for their ease,
If God permit. Go, take these rebels hence;
Let them have martial law: but as for thee,
Friend to thy king and country, still be free.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Be it more or less, what a world is this?
Would I had continued still of the order of knaves,
And never sought knighthood, since it costs so dear.
Sir Roger, I may thank you for all.

speech.speaker: ACTON.
speech.line: Now ‘tis too late to have it remedied,
I prithee, Murley, do not urge me with it.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: Will you away, and make no more to do?

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: Fie, paltry, paltry! To and fro, as occasion serves;
If you be so hasty, take my place.

speech.speaker: HUNT.
speech.line: No, good sir knight, you shall begin in your hand.

speech.speaker: MUR.
speech.line: I could be glad to give my betters place.

scene.scenelocation: Kent. An outer court before Lord Cobham’s house.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports

stagedir.dir: Enter Bishop, lord Warden, Croamer the Sheriff, Lady Cobham, and attendants.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: I tell you, Lady, it’s not possible
But you should know where he conveys himself,
And you have hid him in some secret place.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: My Lord, believe me, as I have a soul,
I know not where my lord my husband is.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Go to, go to, you are an heretic,
And will be forced by torture to confess,
If fair means will not serve to make you tell.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: My husband is a noble gentleman,
And need not hide himself for any fact
That ‘ere I heard of; therefore wrong him not.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Your husband is a dangerous schismatic,
Traitor to God, the King, and common wealth:
And therefore, master Croamer, shrieve of Kent,
I charge you take her to your custody,
And seize the goods of Sir John Oldcastle
To the King’s use. Let her go in no more,
To fetch so much as her apparel out.
There is your warrant from his majesty.

speaker.long: Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports

speech.speaker: WARD.
speech.line: Good my Lord Bishop, pacify your wrath
Against the Lady.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Then let her confess
Where Oldcastle her husband is concealed.

speaker.long: Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports

speech.speaker: WARD.
speech.line: I dare engage mine honor and my life,
Poor gentlewoman, she is ignorant
And innocent of all his practises,
If any evil by him be practiced.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: If, my Lord Warden? Nay, then I charge you,
That all the cinque Ports, whereof you are chief,
Be laid forthwith, that he escape us not.
Shew him his highness’ warrant, Master Shrieve.

speaker.long: Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports

speech.speaker: WARD.
speech.line: I am sorry for the noble gentleman—

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Peace, he comes here; now do your office.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Harpoole, what business have we here in hand?
What makes the Bishop and the Sheriff here?
I fear my coming home is dangerous,
I would I had not made such haste to Cobham.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Be of good cheer, my Lord: if they be foes, we’ll scramble shrewdly with them: if they be friends, they are welcome. One of them (my Lord Warden) is your friend; but me thinks my lady weeps; I like not that.

speech.speaker: CRO.
speech.line: Sir John Oldcastle, Lord Cobham, in the King’s majesty’s name, I arrest you of high treason.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Treason, Master Croamer?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Treason, Master Shrieve? S’blood, what treason?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Harpoole, I charge thee, stir not, but be quiet still.
Do you arrest me, Master Shrieve, for treason?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Yea, of high treason, traitor, heretic.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Defiance in his face that calls me so.
I am as true a loyal gentleman
Unto his highness as my proudest enemy.
The King shall witness my late faithful service,
For safety of his sacred majesty.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: What thou art the king’s hand shall testify:
Shewt him, Lord Warden.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Jesu defend me!
Is’t possible your cunning could so temper
The princely disposition of his mind,
To sign the damage of a loyal subject?
Well, the best is, it bears an antedate,
Procured by my absence, and your malice,
But I, since that, have shewd myself as true
As any churchman that dare challenge me.
Let me be brought before his majesty;
If he acquit me not, then do your worst.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: We are not bound to do king offices
For any traitor, schismatic, nor heretic.
The king’s hand is our warrant for our work,
Who is departed on his way for France,
And at Southhampton doth repose this night.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: O that it were the blessed will of God, that thou and I were within twenty mile of it, on Salisbury plan! I would lose my head if ever thou broughtst thy head hither again.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My Lord Warden o’ the cinque Ports, and my Lord of
Rochester, you are joint Commissioners: favor me so much,
On my expence to bring me to the king.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: What, to Southhampton?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Thither, my good Lord,
And if he do not clear me of all guilt,
And all suspicion of conspiracy,
Pawning his princely warrant for my truth:
I ask no favor, but extremest torture.
Bring me, or send me to him, good my Lord:
Good my Lord Warden, Master Shrieve, entreat.

stagedir.dir: Here the Lord Warden, and Croamer uncover the Bishop, and secretly whisper with him.

speech.line: Come hither, lady—nay, sweet wife, forbear
To heap one sorrow on another’s neck:
Tis grief enough falsely to be accused,
And not permitted to acquit myself;
Do not thou with thy kind respective tears,
Torment thy husband’s heart that bleeds for thee,
But be of comfort. God hath help in store
For those that put assured trust in him.
Dear wife, if they commit me to the Tower,
Come up to London to your sister’s house:
That being near me, you may comfort me.
One solace find I settled in my soul,
That I am free from treason’s very thought:
Only my conscience for the Gospel’s sake
Is cause of all the troubles I sustain.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: O my dear Lord, what shall betide of us?
You to the Tower, and I turned out of doors,
Our substance seized unto his highness’ use,
Even to the garments longing to our backs.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Patience, good madame, things at worst will mend,
And if they do not, yet our lives may end.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Urge it no more, for if an Angel spake,
I swear by sweet saint Peter’s blessed keys,
First goes he to the Tower, then to the stake.

speech.speaker: CRO.
speech.line: But by your leave, this warrant doth not stretch
To imprison her.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: No, turn her out of doors,
Even as she is, and lead him to the Tower,
With guard enough for fear of rescuing.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: O, God requite thee, thou blood-thirsty man.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: May it not be, my Lord of Rochester?
Wherein have I incurred your hate so far,
That my appeal unto the King’s denied?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: No hate of mine, but power of holy church,
Forbids all favor to false heretics.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Your private malice, more than public power,
Strikes most at me, but with my life it ends.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: O that I had the Bishop in that fear,
That once I had his Sumner by our selves!

speech.speaker: CRO.
speech.line: My Lord, yet grant one suit unto us all,
That this same ancient serving man may wait
Upon my lord his master in the Tower.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: This old iniquity, this heretic?
That, in contempt of our church discipline,
Compelled my Sumner to devour his process!
Old Ruffian past-grace, upstart schismatic,
Had not the King prayoud us to pardon you,
Ye had fried for it, you grizzled heretic.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: S’blood, my lord Bishop, you do me wrong. I am neither heretic nor puritan, but of the old church. I’ll swear, drink ale, kiss a wench, go to mass, eat fish all Lent, and fast Fridays with cakes and wine, fruit and spicery, shrive me of my old sins afore Easter, and begin new afore whitsontide.

speech.speaker: CRO.
speech.line: A merry, mad, conceited knave, my lord.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: That knave was simply put upon the Bishop.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Well, God forgive him and I pardon him.
Let him attend his master in the Tower,
For I in charity wish his soul no hurt.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: God bless my soul from such cold charity!

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Too th’ Tower with him, and when my leisure serves,
I will examine him of Articles.
Look, my lord Warden, as you have in charge,
The Shrive perform his office.

speaker.long: Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports

speech.speaker: WARD.
speech.line: Yes, my lord.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: What bringst thou there? What, books of heresy?

speech.speaker: SUM.
speech.line: Yea, my lord, here’s not a latin book, no, not so much as our lady’s Psalter. Here’s the Bible, the testament, the Psalms in meter, the sickman’s salve, the treasure of gladness, and all in English, not so much but the Almanac’s English.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Away with them, to the fire with them, Clun!
Now fie upon these upstart heretics.
All English! Burn them, burn them quickly, Clun!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: But do not, Sumner, as you’ll answer it, for I have there English books, my lord, that I’ll not part with for your Bishopric: Bevis of Hampton, Owlglass, the Friar and the Boy, Eleanor Rumming, Robin hood, and other such godly stories, which if you burn, by this flesh, I’ll make you drink their ashes in Saint Marget’s ale.

scene.scenelocation: The entrance of the Tower.

stagedir.dir: Enter Bishop of Rochester with his three men in livery coats.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: Is it your honor’s pleasure we shall stay,
Or come back in the afternoon to fetch you?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Now you have brought me here into the Tower,
You may go back unto the Porters Lodge,
And send for drink or such things as you want,
Where if I have occasion to employ you,
I’ll send some officer to call you to me.
Into the city go not, I command you:
Perhaps I may have present need to use you.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: We will attend your worship here without.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Do so, I pray you.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: Come, we may have a quart of wine at the Rose at
Barking, I warrant you, and come back an hour before
he be ready to go.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: We must hie us then.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: Let’s away.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Ho, Master Lieutenant.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Who calls there?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: A friend of yours.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: My lord of Rochester! Your honor’s welcome.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Sir, here’s my warrant from the Counsel,
For conference with Sir John Oldcastle,
Upon some matter of great consequence.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Ho, sir John!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Who calls there?

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Harpoole, tell Sir John, that my lord of Rochester
Comes from the counsel to confer with him.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: I will, sir.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: I think you may as safe without suspicion,
As any man in England, as I hear,
For it was you most labored his commitment.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: I did, sir, and nothing repent it, I assure you.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir John Oldcastle and Harpoole.

speech.line: Master Leiftenant, I pray you give us leave,
I must confer here with sir John a little.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: With all my heart, my lord.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: My lord, be ruled by me. Take this occasion while ‘tis offered, and on my life your lordship shall escape.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: No more, I say; peace, lest he should suspect it.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Sir John, I am come unto you from the lords of his highness’ most honorable counsel, to know if yet you do recant your errors, conforming you unto the holy church.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: My lord of Rochester, on good advise,
I see my error, but yet, understand me,
I mean not error in the faith I hold,
But error in submitting to your pleasure;
Therefore, your lordship, without more to do,
Must be a means to help me to escape.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: What means, thou heretic?
Darst thou but lift thy hand against my calling?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: No, not to hurt you for a thousand pound.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Nothing but to borrow your upper garments a little; not a word more, for if you do, you die. Peace, for waking the children. There, put them on, Dispatch, my lord. The window that goes out into the leads is sure enough, I told you that before. There, make you ready. I’ll convey him after, and bind him surely in the inner room.

stagedir.dir: Carries the Bishop into the Tower, and returns.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: This is well begun. God send us happy speed,
Hard shift you see men make in time of need, Harpoole.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Here my Lord; come, come away.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: I marvel that my lord should stay so long.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: He hath sent to seek us, I dare lay my life.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: We come in good time; see, where he is coming.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: I beseech you, good my lord of Rochester, be favorable to my lord and master.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: The inner rooms be very hot and close,
I do not like this air here in the Tower.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: His case is hard my lord.—You shall safely get out of the tower; but I will down upon them, in which time get you away.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Fellow, thou troublest me.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Hear me, my Lord!—Hard under Islington wait you my coming. I will bring my Lady, ready with horses to convey you hence.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Fellow, go back again unto thy Lord and counsel him.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Nay, my good lord of Rochester, I’ll bring you to Saint Albans through the woods, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Villain, away.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Nay, since I am past the tower’s liberty, thou part’st not so.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Clubs, clubs, clubs!

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: Murder, murder, murder!

speech.speaker: 2. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: Down with him!

speech.speaker: 3. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: A villain traitor!

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: You cowardly rogues!

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Who is so bold as dare to draw a sword,
So near unto the entrance of the Tower?

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: This ruffian, servant to Sir John Oldcastle,
Was like to have slain my lord.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Lay hold on him.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Stand off, if you love your puddings.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Help, help, help! Master Lieutenant, help!

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Who’s that within? Some treason in the Tower
Upon my life. Look in; who’s that which calls?

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Without your cloak, my lord of Rochester?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: There, now it works, then let me speed, for now
Is the fittest time for me to scape away.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Why do you look so ghastly and affrighted?

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Oldcastle, that traitor, and his man,
When you had left me to confer with him,
Took, bound, and stript me, as you see,
And left me lying in his inner chamber,
And so departed, and I—

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: And you? Ne’er say that the Lord Cobham’s man
Did here set upon you like to murder you.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: And so he did.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: It was upon his master then he did,
That in the brawl the traitor might escape.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Where is this Harpoole?

speech.speaker: 2. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: Here he was even now.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Where? Can you tell?

speech.speaker: 2. SERV. BISH.
speech.line: They are both escaped.

speech.speaker: LIEUT.
speech.line: Since it so happens that he is escaped,
I am glad you are a witness of the same,
It might have else been laid unto my charge,
That I had been consenting to the fact.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Come, search shall be made for him with expedition,
The havens laid that he shall not escape,
And hue and cry continue through England,
To find this damned, dangerous heretic.

scene.scenelocation: A room in Lord Cobham’s house in Kent.

stagedir.dir: Enter Cambridge, Scroop, and Gray, as in a chamber, and set down at a table, consulting about their treason: King Harry and Suffolk listening at the door.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: In mine opinion, Scroop hath well advised,
Poison will be the only aptest mean,
And fittest for our purpose to dispatch him.

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: But yet there may be doubt in their delivery.
Harry is wise; therefore, Earl of Cambridge,
I judge that way not so convenient.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: What think you then of this? I am his bedfellow,
And unsuspected nightly sleep with him.
What if I venture in those silent hours,
When sleep hath sealed up all mortal eyous,
To murder him in bed? How like you that?

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Herein consists no safety for your self,
And, you disclosed, what shall become of us?
But this day (as you know) he will aboard—
The winds so fair—and set away for France.
If, as he goes, or entering in the ship,
It might be done, then it were excellent.

speech.speaker: GRAY.
speech.line: Why any of these, or, if you will, I’ll cause
A present sitting of the Counsel, wherein
I will pretend some matter of such weight
As needs must have his royal company,
And so dispatch him in the Counsel chamber.

speech.speaker: CAMB.
speech.line: Tush, yet I hear not any thing to purpose.
I wonder that lord Cobham stays so long;
His counsel in this case would much avail us.

stagedir.dir: They rise from the table, and the King steps in to them, with his soldiers.

speech.speaker: SCROOP.
speech.line: What, shall we rise thus, and determine nothing?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: That were a shame indeed; no, sit again,
And you shall have my counsel in this case.
If you can find no way to kill this King,
Then you shall see how I can further you:
Scroop’s way of poison was indifferent,
But yet, being bed-fellow unto the King,
And unsuspected sleeping in his bosom,
In mine opinion, that’s the likelier way,
For such false friends are able to do much,
And silent night is Treason’s fittest friend.
Now, Cambridge, in his setting hence for France,
Or by the way, or as he goes abroad,
To do the deed, what was indifferent too,
Yet somewhat doubtful, might I speak my mind.
For many reasons needless now to urge.
Mary, Lord Gray came something near the point:
To have the King at counsel, and there murder him,
As Caesar was, amongst his dearest friends:
None like to that, if all were of his mind.
Tell me, oh tell me, you, bright honor’s stains,
For which of all my kindnesses to you,
Are you become thus traitors to your king,
And France must have the spoil of harry’s life?

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Oh pardon us, dread lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: How, pardon you? That were a sin indeed.
Drag them to death, which justly they deserve,
And France shall dearly buy this villainy,
So soon as we set footing on her breast.
God have the praise for our deliverance;
And next, our thanks, Lord Cobham, is to thee,
True perfect mirror of nobility.

scene.scenelocation: A high road near St. Albans.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Come, Doll, come; be merry, wench.
Farewell, Kent, we are not fond for thee.
Be lusty, my lass, come, for Lancashire,
We must nip the Boung for these crowns.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Why, is all the gold spent already that you had the other day?

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Gone, Doll, gone; flown, spent, vanished: the devil, drink and the dice has devoured all.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: You might have left me in Kent, that you might, until
you had been better provided, I could have stayoud at
Cobham.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: No, Doll, no, I’ll none of that; Kent’s too hot, Doll, Kent’s too hot. The weathercock of Wrotham will crow no longer: we have pluckt him, he has lost his feathers; I have pruned him bare, left him thrice; is moulted, is moulted, wench.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Faith, sir John, I might have gone to service again. Old master Harpoole told me he would provide me a mistress.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Peace, Doll, peace. Come, mad wench, I’ll make thee an honest woman; we’ll into Lancashire to our friends: the troth is, I’ll marry thee. We want but a little money to buy us a horse, and to spend by the way; the next sheep that comes shall lose his fleece, we’ll have these crowns, wench, I warrant thee.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Irishman with his master slain.

speech.line: Stay, who comes here? Some Irish villain, me thinks, that has slain a man, and draws him out of the way to rifle him. Stand close, Doll, we’ll see the end.

stagedir.dir: The Irishman falls to rifle his master.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Alas, poe mester, Sir Rishard Lee, be saint Patrick is rob and cut thy trote for dee shaine, and dy money, and dee gold ring be me truly: is love thee well, but now dow be kill, thee bee shitten kanave.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Stand, sirra. What art thou?

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Be saint Patrick, mester, is pore Irisman, is a leufter.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Sirra, sirra, you are a damned rogue. You have killed a man here, and rifled him of all that he has. S’blood, you rogue, deliver, or I’ll not leave you so much as an Irish hair above your shoulders, you whoreson Irish dog. Sirra, untruss presently; come, off and dispatch, or by this cross I’ll fetch your head off as clean as a bark.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Wee’s me, saint Patrick! Ise kill me mester for chain and his ring, and nows be rob of all: mee’s undoo.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Avant, you rascal! Go, sirra, be walking. Come, Doll, the devil laughs, when one thief robs another: come, mad wench, we’ll to saint Albans, and revel in our bower; hey, my brave girl.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: O thou art old, sir John when all’s done, i’faith.

scene.scenelocation: St. Albans. The entrance of a carrier’s inn.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Host of the Bell Innn with the Irishman.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Be me tro, mester, is pore Irisman, is want ludging, is have no money, is starve and cold: good mester, give her some meat; is famise and tie.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: I’faith, my fellow, I have no lodging, but what I keep for my guess, that I may not disappoint: as for meat thou shalt have such as there is, and if thou wilt lie in the barn, there’s fair straw, and room enough.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Is thank my mester hartily, de straw is good bed for me.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Ho, Robin!

speech.speaker: ROB.
speech.line: Who calls?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Shew this poor Irishman into the barn. Go, sirra.

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Ho, who’s within here? Who looks to the horses? God’s hat! Here’s fine work: the hens in the manger, and the hogs in the litter. A bots found you all; here’s a house well looked to, y’vaith.

speech.speaker: KATE.
speech.line: Mas, goffe Club, I’se very cawd.

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Get in, Kate, get in to fire and warm thee. Ho! John Hostler.

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: What, gaffer Club? Welcome to Saint Albans. How does all our friends in Lancashire?

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Well, God have mercy, John. How does Tom? Where’s he?

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: O, Tom is gone from hence; he’s at the three horse-loves at Stony-stratford. How does old Dick Dunne?

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: God’s hat, old Dunne has been moyourd in a slough in Brickhill-lane, a plague found it; yonder is such abomination weather as never was seen.

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: God’s hat, thief, have one half peck of peas and oats more for that: as I am John Ostler, he has been ever as good a jade as ever traveled.

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Faith, well said, old Jack; thou art the old lad still.

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: Come, Gaffer Club, unload, unload, and get to supper, and I’ll rub dun the while. Come.

scene.scenelocation: St. Albans. A room in the carrier’s inn.

stagedir.dir: Enter the host, Sir John Oldcastle, and Harpoole.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Sir, you are welcome to this house, to such as here is with all my heart, but, by the mass, I fear your lodging will be the worst. I have but two beds, and they are both in a chamber, and the carrier and his daughter lies in the one, and you and your wife must lie in the other.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: In faith, sir, for myself I do not greatly pass.
My wife is weary, and would be at rest,
For we have traveled very far today;
We must be content with such as you have.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: But I cannot tell how to do with your man.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: What, hast thou never an empty room in thy house for me?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Not a bed, by my troth. There came a poor Irishman, and I lodged him in the barn, where he has fair straw, though he have nothing else.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Well, mine host, I pray thee help me to a pair of fair sheets, and I’ll go lodge with him.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: By the mass, that thou shalt; a good pair of hempen sheets, were never lain in. Come.

scene.scenelocation: St. Albans. A street.

stagedir.dir: Enter Constable of St. Albans, Mayor of St. Albans, and Watch.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: What? Have you searched the town?

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: All the town, sir; we have not left a house unsearched that uses to lodge.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: Surely, my lord of Rochester was then deceived,
Or ill informed of Sir John Oldcastle,
Or if he came this way he’s past the town.
He could not else have scaped you in the search.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: The privy watch hath been abroad all night,
And not a stranger lodgeth in the town
But he is known; only a lusty priest
We found in bed with a pretty wench,
That says she is his wife—yonder at the sheeres;
But we have charged the host with his forth coming
Tomorrow morning.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: What think you best to do?

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Faith, master mayor, here’s a few straggling houses beyond the bridge, and a little Inn where carriers use to lodge, though I think sure he would ne’er lodge there: but we’ll go search, and the rather, because there came notice to the town the last night of an Irishman, that had done a murder, whom we are to make search for.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: Come, I pray you, and be circumspect.

scene.scenelocation: St. Albans. Before the Carrier’s Inn.

stagedir.dir: Enter Two Officers of the Watch.

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: First beset the house, before you begin the search.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Content; every man take a several place.

stagedir.dir: Here is heard a great noise within. “Keep, keep, strike him down there, down with him.”
Enter Constable with the Irishman in Harpoole’s apparel.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Come, you villainous heretic, confess where your master is.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Vat mester?

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: Vat mester, you counterfeit rebel? This shall not serve your turn.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Be sent Patrick I ha no mester.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Where’s the lord Cobham, Sir John Oldcastle, that lately is escaped out of the Tower?

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Vat lort Cobham?

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: You counterfeit, this shall not serve you; we’ll torture you, we’ll make you to confess where that arch-heretic, Lord Cobham, is. Come, bind him fast.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Ahone, ahone, ahone, a Cree!

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Ahone, you crafty rascal!

scene.scenelocation: St. Albans. The yard of the Inn.

stagedir.dir: Lord Cobham comes out in his gown stealing.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Harpoole, Harpoole, I hear a marvelous noise about the house. God warrant us, I fear we are pursued. What, Harpoole.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Who calls there?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Tis I. Dost thou not hear a noise about the house?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Yes, mary, do I. —Zwounds, I can not find my hose. This Irish rascal that was lodged with me all night hath stolen my apparel, and has left me nothing but a lowsy mantle, and a pair of brogues. Get up, get up, and if the carrier and his wench be asleep, change you with them as he hath done with me, and see if we can escape.

stagedir.dir: A noise again heard about the house, a pretty while. Then enter the Constable, meeting Harpoole in the Irishman’s apparel.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Stand close, here comes the Irishman that did the murder. By all tokens, this is he.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: And perceiving the house beset, would get away.
Stand, sirra.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: What are thou that bidst me stand?

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: I am the Officer, and am come to search for an Irishman, such a villain as thy self, that hast murdered a man this last night by the high way.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: S’blood, Constable, art thou mad? Am I an Irishman?

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: Sirra, we’ll find you an Irishman before we part. Lay hold upon him.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Make him fast. O thou bloody rogue!

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Cobham and his lady in the carrier and wenches apparel.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: What, will these Ostlers sleep all day?
Good morrow, good morrow. Come, wench, come.
Saddle! Saddle! Now afore God too fair days, ha?

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Who comes there?

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: Oh, ‘tis Lancashire carrier. Let him pass.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: What, will no body open the gates here?
Come, let’s int’ stable to look to our capons.

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Host! Why hostler! Z’wooks, here’s such a bomination company of boys. A pox of this pigsty at the house end. It fills all the house full of fleas. Hostler! Hostler!

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: Who calls there? What would you have?

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Z’wooks, do you rob your guests? Do you lodge rogues and slaves, and scoundrels, ha? They ha stolen our clothes here. Why, hostler!

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: A murrein choke you, what a bawlin’ you keep.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: How now, what would the carrier have? Look up there.

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: They say that the man and woman that lay by them have stolen their clothes.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What, are the strange folks up yet that come in yesternight?

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: What, mine host, up so early?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What, master Mayor, and master Constable!

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: We are come to seek for some suspected persons,
And such as here we found, have apprehended.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Carrier and Kate in Lord Cobham and Lady’s apparel.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Who comes here?

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Who comes here? A plague found ome! You bawl, quoth a! Ods hat, I’ll forzwear your house. You lodged a fellow and his wife by that ha’ run away with our ‘parrel, and left us such gew-gaws here!—Come Kate, come to me. Thowse dizeard, i’faith.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: Mine host, know you this man?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Yes, master Mayor, I’ll give my word for him. Why, neighbor
Club, how comes this gear about?

speech.speaker: HOSTLER.
speech.line: Now, a fowl on’t, I can not make this gew-gaw stand on my head. Now the lads and the lasses won flout me too too—

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: How came this man and woman thus attired?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Here came a man and woman hither this last night, which I did take for substantial people, and lodged all in one chamber by these folks, methinks, have been so bold to change apparel, and gone away this morning ‘ere they rose.

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: That was that villain traitor, Oldcastle, that thus escaped us. Make out hue and cry yet after him. Keep fast that traitorous rebel. His servant, there. Farewell, mine host.

speech.speaker: CLUB.
speech.line: Come, Kate Oldham. Thou and Ise trimly dizard.

scene.scenelocation: A wood near St. Albans.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir John Oldcastle and his Lady disguised.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Come, Madam, happily escaped; here let us sit.
This place is far remote from any path,
And here awhile our weary limbs may rest,
To take refreshing, free from the pursuit
Of envious Rochester.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: But where, my Lord,
Shall we find rest for our disquiet minds?
There dwell untamed thoughts that hardly stop,
To such abasement of disdained rags.
We were not wont to travel thus by night,
Especially on foot.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: No matter, love;
Extremities admit no better choice,
And were it not for thee, say froward time
Imposed a greater task, I would esteem it
As lightly as the wind that blows upon us;
But in thy sufference I am doubly tasked.
Thou wast not wont to have the earth thy stool,
Nor the moist dewy grass thy pillow, nor
Thy chamber to be the wide horizon.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: How can it seem a trouble, having you
A partner with me in the worst I feel?
No, gentle Lord, your presence would give ease
To death it self, should he now seize upon me.
Behold what my foresight hath underta’en

stagedir.dir: Here’s bread and cheese and a bottle.

speech.line: For fear we faint; they are but homely cates,
Yet sauced with hunger, they may seem as sweet
As greater dainties we were wont to taste.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Praise be to him whose plenty sends both this
And all things else our mortal bodies need;
Nor scorn we this poor feeding, nor the state
We now are in, for what is it on earth,
Nay, under heaven, continues at a stay?
Ebbs not the sea, when it hath overflown?
Follows not darkness when the day is gone?
And see we not sometime the eyou of heaven
Dimmed with overflying clouds: there’s not that work
Of careful nature, or of cunning art,
(How strong, how beauteous, or how rich it be)
But falls in time to ruin. Here, gentle Madame,
In this one draught I wash my sorrow down.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: And I, encouraged with your cheerful speech,
Will do the like.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Pray God poor Harpoole come.
If he should fall into the Bishop’s hands,
Or not remember where we bade him meet us,
It were the thing of all things else, that now
Could breed revolt in this new peace of mind.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: Fear not, my Lord, he’s witty to devise,
And strong to execute a present shift.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: That power be still his guide hath guided us!
My drowsy eyous wax heavy: early rising,
Together with the travel we have had,
Make me that I could gladly take a nap,
Were I persuaded we might be secure.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: Let that depend on me: whilst you do sleep,
I’ll watch that no misfortune happen us.
Lay then your head upon my lap, sweet Lord,
And boldly take your rest.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: I shall, dear wife,
Be too much trouble to thee.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: Urge not that;
My duty binds me, and your love commands.
I would I had the skill with tuned voice
To draw on sleep with some sweet melody,
But imperfection, and unaptness too,
Are both repugnant: fear insert the one,
The other nature hath denied me use.
But what talk I of means to purchase that,
Is freely happened? Sleep with gentle hand
Hath shut his eyou-lids. Oh victorious labor,
How soon thy power can charm the bodies sense?
And now thou likewise climbst unto my brain,
Making my heavy temples stoop to thee.
Great God of heaven from danger keep us free.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Richard Lee, and his two men.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: A murder closely done, and in my ground?
Search carefully, if any where it were,
This obscure thicket is the likeliest place.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV. LEE.
speech.line: Sir, I have found the body stiff with cold,
And mangled cruelly with many wounds.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: Look if thou knowest him, turn his body up.—
Alack, it is my son, my son and heir,
Whom two years since I sent to Ireland,
To practice there the discipline of war,
And coming home (for so he wrote to me)
Some savage heart, some bloody devilish hand,
Either in hate, or thirsting for his coin,
Hath here sluiced out his blood. Unhappy hour,
Accursed place, but most inconstant fate,
That hadst reserved him from the bullet’s fire,
And suffered him to scape the wood-karn’s fury,
Didst here ordain the treasure of his life,
(Even here within the arms of tender peace,
And where security gave greatest hope)
To be consumed by treason’s wasteful hand!
And what is most afflicting to my soul,
That this his death and murder should be wrought
Without the knowledge by whose means twas done.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV. LEE.
speech.line: Not so, sir; I have found the authors of it.
See where they sit, and in their bloody fists,
The fatal instruments of death and sin.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: Just judgment of that power, whose gracious eyou,
Loathing the sight of such a heinous fact,
Dazzled their senses with benumbing sleep,
Till their unhallowed treachery were known!
Awake, you monsters; murderers, awake;
Tremble for horror; blush, you cannot choose,
Beholding this inhumane deed of yours.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: What mean you, sir, to trouble weary souls,
And interrupt us of our quiet sleep?

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: Oh devilish! Can you boast unto your selves
Of quiet sleep, having within your hearts
The guilt of murder waking, that with cries
Deafs the loud thunder, and solicits heaven
With more than Mandrake’s shrieks for your offense?

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: What murder? You upbraid us wrongfully.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: Can you deny the fact? See you not here
The body of my son by you mis-done?
Look on his wounds, look on his purple hue:
Do we not find you where the deed was done?
Were not your knives fast closed in your hands?
Is not this cloth an argument beside,
Thus stained and spotted with his innocent blood?
These speaking characters, were nothing else
To plead against you, would convict you both.
Bring them away, bereavers of my joy.
At Hartford, where the Sizes now are kept,
Their lives shall answer for my son’s lost life.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: As we are innocent, so may we speed.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: As I am wronged, so may the law proceed.

scene.scenelocation: St. Albans. A street.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: Enter Bishop of Rochester, Constable of St. Albans, with Sir John of Wrotham, Doll his wench, and the Irishman in Harpoole’s apparel.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: What intricate confusion have we here?
Not two hours since we apprehended one,
In habit Irish, but in speech not so:
And now you bring another, that in speech
Is altogether Irish, but in habit
Seems to be English: yea and more than so,
The servant of that heretic Lord Cobham.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Fait, me be no servant of the lord Cobham,
Me be Mack Chane of Vister.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Otherwise called Harpoole of Kent; go to, sir,
You cannot blind us with your broken Irish.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Trust me, my Lord Bishop, whether Irish,
Or English, Harpoole or not Harpoole, that
I leave to be decided by the trial:
But sure I am this man by face and speech
Is he that murdered young sir Richard Lee—
I met him presently upon the fact—
And that he slew his master for that gold;
Those jewels, and that chain I took from him.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: Well, our affairs do call us back to London,
So that we cannot prosecute the cause,
As we desire to do; therefore we leave
The charge with you, to see they be conveyed
To Hartford Sise: both this counterfeit
And you, Sir John of Wrotham, and your wench,
For you are culpable as well as they,
Though not for murder, yet for felony.
But since you are the means to bring to light
This graceless murder, you shall bear with you
Our letters to the Judges of the bench,
To be your friends in what they lawful may.

speech.speaker: BISH.
speech.line: So, away with them.

scene.scenelocation: Hertford. A Hall of Justice.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

stagedir.dir: Enter Jailer and his man, bringing forth Oldcastle.

speech.speaker: JAIL.
speech.line: Bring forth the prisoners, see the court prepared;
The Justices are coming to the bench.
So, let him stand; away, and fetch the rest.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Oh, give me patience to endure this scourge,
Thou that art fountain of that virtuous stream,
And though contempt, false witness, and reproach
Hang on these iron gyves, to press my life
As low as earth, yet strengthen me with faith,
That I may mount in spirit above the clouds.

stagedir.dir: Enter Jailer, bringing in Lady Oldcastle and Harpoole.

speech.line: Here comes my lady: sorrow, ‘tis for her
Thy wound is grievous; else I scoff at thee.
What, and poor Harpoole! Art thou ith briars too?

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Ifaith, my Lord, I am in, get out how I can.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: Say, gentle Lord, for now we are alone,
And may confer, shall we confess in brief,
Of whence, and what we are, and so prevent
The accusation is commenced against us?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: What will that help us? Being known, sweet love,
We shall for heresy be put to death,
For so they term the religion we profess.
No, if it be ordained we must die,
And at this instant, this our comfort be,
That of the guilt imposed, our souls are free.

speech.speaker: HARP.
speech.line: Yea, yea, my lord, Harpoole is so resolved.
I wreak of death the less, in that I die
Not by the sentence of that envious priest
The Bishop of Rochester: oh, were it he,
Or by his means that I should suffer here,
It would be double torment to my soul.

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: Well, be it then according as heaven please.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Judge, two Justices, Mayor of Saint Albans, Lord Powis and his lady, and old Sir Richard Lee. The Judge and Justices take their places.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: Now, Master Mayor, what gentleman is that,
You bring with you before us and the bench?

speech.speaker: ALBANS.
speech.line: The Lord Powis, if it like your honor,
And this his Lady, travelling toward Wales,
Who, for they lodged last night within my house,
And my Lord Bishop did lay search for such,
Were very willing to come on with me,
Lest for their sakes suspicion me might wrong.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: We cry your honor mercy, good my Lord,
Wilt please you take your place. Madame, your ladyship
May here or where you will repose your self,
Until this business now in hand be past.

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: I will withdraw into some other room,
So that your Lordship and the rest be pleased.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: With all our hearts: attend the Lady there.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Wife, I have eyed yond prisoners all this while,
And my conceit doth tell me, ‘tis our friend,
The noble Cobham, and his virtuous Lady.

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: I think no less: are they suspected, trow you,
For doing of this murder?

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: What is means
I cannot tell, but we shall know anon.
Mean space as you pass by them, ask the question,
But do it secretly, you be not seen,
And make some sign that I may know your mind.

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: My Lord Cobham? Madam?

stagedir.dir: As she passeth over the stage by them.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: No Cobham now, nor madam, as you love us,
But John of Lancashire, and Ione his wife.

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: Oh tell, what is it that our love can do,
To pleasure you? For we are bound to you.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Nothing but this, that you conceal our names;
So, gentle lady, pass for being spied.

speech.speaker: LADY POW.
speech.line: My heart I leave, to bear part of your grief.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: Call the prisoners to the bar. Sir Richard Lee,
What evidence can you bring against these people,
To prove them guilty of the murder done?

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: This bloody towel and these naked knives,
Beside we found them sitting by the place,
Where the dead body lay, within a bush.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: What answer you why law should not proceed,
According to the evidence given in,
To tax you with the penalty of death?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: That we are free from murder’s very thoughts,
And know not how the gentleman was slain.

speech.speaker: 1. JUST.
speech.line: How came this linen cloth so bloody then?

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: My husband hot with travelling, my lord,
His nose gushed out a bleeding, that was it.

speech.speaker: 2. JUST.
speech.line: But wherefore were your sharp edged knives unsheathed?

speech.speaker: LADY COB.
speech.line: To cut such simple victual as we had.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: Say we admit this answer to those articles,
What made you in so private a dark nook,
So far remote from any common path,
As was the thick where the dead corpse was thrown?

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: Journeying, my lord, from London from the term,
Down into Lancashire where we do dwell,
And what with age and travel being faint,
We gladly sought a place where we might rest,
Free from resort of other passengers,
And so we strayoud into that secret corner.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: These are but ambages to drive of time,
And linger Justice from her purposed end.
But who are these?

stagedir.dir: Enter the Constable, bringing in the Irishman, Sir John of Wrotham, and Doll.

speech.speaker: CONST. ALB.
speech.line: Stay Judgement, and release those innocents,
For here is he, whose hand hath done the deed,
For which they stand indicted at the bar,—
This savage villain, this rude Irish slave.
His tongue already hath confessed the fact,
And here is witness to confirm as much.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Yes, my good Lords, no sooner had he slain
His loving master for the wealth he had,
But I upon the instant met with him,
And what he purchased with the loss of blood:
With strokes I presently bereaved him of;
Some of the which is spent, the rest remaining
I willingly surrender to the hands
Of old sir Richard Lee, as being his.
Beside, my Lord Judge, I greet your honor
With letters from my Lord of Rochester.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: Is this the wolf whose thirsty throat did drink
My dear son’s blood? Art thou the snake
He cherished, yet with envious piercing sting
Assailed him mortally? Foul stigmatic,
Thou venom of the country where thou livedst,
And pestilence of this: were it not that law
Stands ready to revenge thy cruelty,
Traitor to God, thy master, and to me,
These hands should be thy executioner.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: Patience, sir Richard Lee, you shall have justice,
And he the guerdon of his base desert.
The fact is odious; therefore, take him hence,
And being hanged until the wretch be dead,
His body after shall be handed in chains
Near to the place where he did act the murder.

speech.speaker: IRISH.
speech.line: Prethee, Lord shudge, let me have mine own clothes, my strouces there, and let me be hanged in a with after my cuntry—the Irish—fashion.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: Go to; away with him. And now, Sir John,
Although by you this murder came to light,
And therein you have well deserved, yet upright law,
So will not have you be excused and quit,
For you did rob the Irishman, by which
You stand attainted here of felony.
Beside, you have been lewd, and many years
Led a lascivious, unbeseeming life.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: Oh but, my Lord, he repents, sir John repents, and he will mend.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: In hope thereof, together with the favor,
My Lord of Rochester entreats for you,
We are content you shall be proved.

speaker.long: Sir John the Parson of Wrotham

speech.speaker: WROTH.
speech.line: I thank you, good Lordship.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: These other falsely here accused, and brought
In peril wrongfully, we in like sort
Do set at liberty, paying their fees.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: That office, if it please you, I will do,
For countries sake, because I know them well.
They are my neighbors, therefore of my cost
Their charges shall be paid.

speech.speaker: LEE.
speech.line: And for amends,
Touching the wrong unwittingly I have done,
There are a few crowns more for them to drink.

speech.speaker: JUDGE.
speech.line: Your kindness merits praise, Sir Richard Lee:
So let us hence.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Lord Powis and Oldcastle.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: But Powis still must stay.
There yet remains a part of that true love
He owes his noble friend unsatisfied,
And unperformed, which first of all doth bind me
To gratulate your lordship’s safe delivery,
And then entreat, that since unlooked for thus
We here are met, your honor would vouchsafe,
To ride with me to Wales, where to my power,
(Though not to quittance those great benefits,
I have received of you) yet both my house,
My purse, my servants, and what else I have,
Are all at your command. Deny me not;
I know the Bishop’s hate pursues you so,
As there’s no safety in abiding here.

speech.speaker: COB.
speech.line: ‘Tis true, my Lord, and God forgive him for it.

speech.speaker: POW.
speech.line: Then, let us hence. You shall be straight provided
Of lusty geldings, and once entered Wales,
Well may the Bishop hunt, but, spite his face,
He never more shall have the game in chase.
